reviewText:
I've played this game since I was 10 years old when it came out in america.

The best way to describe maplestory is a deep, deep hole out in the woods.
When you are bored and looking for something to do you fall into this hole.
At first you are scared, you panic and try to get out of the hole.
But slowly, you begin you like it in the hole.
You spend thousands of dollars on making this hole cooler, nicer, and do more dps.
You meet friends, lovers, and ♥♥♥♥♥♥s inside of this hole, it begins to feel like a community.
Then high school girl drama will go down, and you will sell all your gear and quit.
You will struggle to climb out of this hole. And finally....you're out.

You go back to the way your life was before, and you become happy again.

After a couple of months...you feel this craving...this...hunger...
You miss the hole. Sure, the hole has its ups and downs...but you...you were safe in the hole...you were...home...
So you go back, and thus begins the never ending downward spiral of your life.

10/10 would quit and play again.

reviewText:
For claification sake, I've played this game since Beta and I love the overall animation and playstyle imaged as a 2D platformer. I guess this really hit a nostalgia nerve for me and my yearning for the old Mario Brothers mechanics. And while I hate to bash something I fell in love with, this is no longer the game that I use to know.

Back in the early days of MapleStory, you had your 4 standard classes: Mage, Warrior, Archer, Thief. Mage and Warrior had 3 subsets each; Archer and Thief had 2 subsets. Finding equipment and hanging out with friends was easy because there was just a few servers and not that many maps. The level cap was set as a crazy 200, but the mindless grinding wasn't so bad, cause you could easily be with your friends and if you found an equip you couldn't use, one of them could and vice versa.

But Maplestory grew. On the surface, you would think this is a good thing; more people = more friends = more equips. True, but Nexon saw this as an excellent opportunity to milk its players through microtransactions.

As the game grew, Nexon built more servers and maps, creating virtual spacial rifts between players. It became more and more difficult to get to the same map as a friend without using a teleport rock (a microtransaction item) or wasting a bunch of time. Nexon created pets, vanity items, world transfers, shops; all for real money. When that wasn't enough, they created more character types, those who couldn't share the cash shop items with the original characters, essentially urging players to rebuy cash items. The new characters also lead to the nerfing of some of the original characters under the guise of improved" for rebalancing issues. Nexon raised the level cap to 250
date: milking players for even longer. They created a lottery system called gachapon for in-game items using real money
recommended: not to mention special event "lotteries".\n\nDon't play Maplestory. It's not what it use to be. The fun is sucked out of it. Don't waste tons of time and money on it like I did."

reviewText:
MapleStory was one of the first MMORPG titles I've had the chance of playing, besides Runescape Classic (which was a looong time ago).

After a revisit of this game (after many years of on and off playing), as well as THOUSANDS of dollars spent, I cannot say I am willing to recommend this game.

FIrstly, MapleStory is one of the few 2D side-scrolling MMORPGs that try to mix 'cute' and 'breathtaking' together, and at times, they do it very well. Some landscapes are huge, the original lore and locations were very well done, and one can be trapped in the game's beauty for long periods of time. Heck, even getting lost in that game was fun. However, with the changes as of the last two to three years, a lot of the beauty has been lost. In order to cater to the broader generation of players who demand instant gratification, they have changed out most of the old expansive locations and replaced them with compacted versions - so that players can traverse the world much more quickly. However, by doing so, they've stuffed all the game's content into the newer maps, which makes most of the world appear small and claustrophobic.

The music score for this game is wonderful. Whether you're inside the forests of Ellinia, or exploring the depths of Ludibrium,  the background music really amplifies the mystery and beauty the game world is trying to become.

The original MapleStory had a handful of classes, and each of them were unique, but overall balanced. Now, each large 'class update' seems to focus on newer 'Hero' characters, most who severely outclass the older counterparts in terms of damage and flashiness. In fact, there are so many different 'Heroes' nowadays, it saddens me to say that you'll rarely run into the older classes anymore, except in the case of Legacy worlds.

The Cash Shop isn't all too great either. In addition to the standard cosmetic items and EXP boosts that one would commonly find in Free-2-Play MMOs, there are also items which give you in game currency, some which would offer you lowered failure chances when upgrading items. The latter gives players who spend a huge lead over players who don't, and this is made obvious by the overly high prices those items fetch on the marketplace.

Combine that with a marketplace that doesn't let players open one without forking cash (and depending on how much cash you're willing to spend, it also determines whether you'll have to stay logged in to sell items)(players are only able to trade, so they'll have to solicit people in the market entrances) and a bad support team, I truly cannot recommend this game to anyone. MapleStory's golden days are long gone, and what's left is a carcass of what was once a masterpiece.

reviewText:
I have no idea if Steam will say at all if I've played Maplestory but I promise you all I have put a lot of time into this game and absolutely loved every minute. Unfortunately Maplestory just became completely uninteresting since I've tried to relive it. And it makes me really sad. Maplestory originally had the classes we all see in every MMO (no matter how hard other MMO's try to make it different) and of course also like every MMO it started off simple. One big difference of course was the fact that it was a 2D sidescrolling MMOPRG and it's done so beautifully. You can make different faces at people depending on how you feel which was really fun before the cliche lol" and "lmao" texts we all now universally know. Getting weapons was also a little more unique since most MMO's just milk weapons. Now a lot of MMORPG's have bows with unlimited arrows and guns with unlimited bullets. Maplestory made you buy arrows and throwing stars/shuriken if you wanted to be a ranged class. And Mesos (Maplestory currency) was hard to come by at low levels making it even more challenging since you had to actually ask for money from time to time.

When I originally loved this amazing piece of gaming art you had to use a taxi to get to different cities (which you still do at least) and use flying boats to get to different continents. This was a huge deal because it allowed you to just settle down for a short time and actually talk to people; and listen to music along the way. Now this is not the case. There were no overpowered and annoyingly voice acted 'Hero' classes that literally kill everything in their paths with ease. You really had to work to get more powerful back then and you also needed to manually know what your stats needed to be for your class. Maplestory added more powerful classes over time but they were never 'Hero' status. Yes they got more powerful due to their unique skills compared to the default classes; however you still needed to start off as a default class and work your way into the more unique class you selected and leveling was still just as hard for you as the rest.

The music is still the same Maplestory anime music I know and love. I just wish it could be heard with the game I knew and loved. For all you new players out there reading this review it'll mean close to nothing probably. To shorten what I just said: Maplestory used to be a surprisingly vast game filled with lots of social opportunity and hours upon hours of questing and leveling. It's a shell of its former self now. This does not mean I say it's a bad game. It's still good and worth the try. But unfortunately you have missed the golden age that was Maplestory. It's all milked down and I can't recommend it in its state now. What used to take a couple weeks to a month takes less than a day now. Bosses that originally required a full team can easily be defeated solo and the monsters that were originally intimidating and powerful are powerless. The challenge is gone. I will miss you Maplestory."

reviewText:
MapleStory is that one game you're probably never going to find another of its calibre. It has that feel of nostalgia, even if you're new to the game. Attractive art styles look cartoony and cute while retaining 2d and pixelation draw people in this game with its surprising uniqueness. Maplestory has been breathing since 2005, but is it stable breathing?

-Leveling-

Maplestory was in its prime long back when generation Y was around 6 years old (2005 debut). If you compare the leveling from old Maplestory to post-big bang Maplestory, youll notice a huge difference. Its easier to hit level 100 nowadays, but back then whoever was over level 100 was considered a god. Old Maplestory had challenging leveling, so challenging that it took months to hit just 50. If you see the game now, it's a joke to hit 50, a 5 year old could do it in an hour.

Of course Maplestory's leveling system will never be as good as it was back then; it evolves for newer audience because Nexon know the older audience will eventually quit. This is an instant gradification era, people want to level up quickly, not like a snail, to a point where it bores them to level up only 10 times a week. So, Nexon implemented an easier leveling system. One could argue that Nexon actually saved the game from dying off earlier.

I won't argue anymore about Nexon saving the game with the leveling system, I used to think it was a saving throw, but I realized it's pretty much easy if you have enough change in your pockets. You can buy your levels. That's right. Nexon milked the leveling system for money. (by buy I mean buying 2x coupons and smashing keys to hit 200 easy peasy granted you have the money)

-You ultimately don't have to spend money, but it makes you look/feel like trash-

Nexon milked this game so much that its clear instead of a thick white. You ultimately don't have to spend money, since you CAN get anything you need without money. Let me elobrate, of course its convenient to buy cubes instead of pressing your mouse to farm for minerals and craft one, so the obvious logic is to do illegal activites and buy nexon points with mesos, the ingame currency, from a shady dealer with -239 downvotes. This game isn't really Pay 2 Win, it's more of Pay 4 Convenience. P4C makes you look like japanese eyecandy to people who get turned on to pixels, and makes your equipment hit like train, if that train holds 5 billion damage per hit.

But if you don't P4C, you look like absolute crap until you muster enough mesos to buy one permanent nx item that looks decent. Gaining mesos from scratch is a timewaster too, because to merch (the term for buying low, selling high) without staring at your screen and hitting up and down to cycle messages, you have to pay real money to get a stand that does it for you, for about a month. Then you gotta buy it again if you want to merch, or get Carpal Tunnel. Oh, also, unless you spend alot of time and logical thinking on cubing and boosting stats on CRA, might as well fight with a stick because you are doing absolutely nothing to bosses that matter.

-The Community-

It sucks. Everyone will screw you over. I've seen too many stories when people grow up and try something like CSGO and leave for a month and the guild they had a blood pact with kicks them out, no matter how much they've contributed real life money for. People rarely work together anymore with strangers, guilds are just IRL friend camaradies, or a bunch of snobs who have superiority issues. Nexon realized this, but made it worse because they've made the entire game soloable (of course with money.) The community is just like anti-social teenagers at that one lunch table, if those teenagers tell you to CC if you step into their precious room.

-Conclusion-

This game, stripped of everything but gameplay, is so great. I love Maplestory's gameplay. I love it. But Nexon made a semi-working money making machine off of it, and completely ruined it for the veterans. I still play it on and off like that one chick in middle school, but Nexon makes so many schemes for cash and I can't believe people are blindlessly falling for it. Don't be tempted to buy that 90 day hair. Either voice your opinion of change to Nexon, or leave the game. It's not worth your time.

reviewText:
I remember waking up as a kid, excited and eager to start up my dad's computer, hopping into the world of Maplestory, ready to take on whatever the game was going to throw at me that day. Needless to say, I was hooked. The cartoony yet oddly satisfying visuals, the huge world that was set before me, the deceptively simple class system, all things that I adored about it. For a while, I couldn't get enough of this game. It was my first MMO ever, and, to this day, probably still my favorite. Nothing comes close to the fun I had while killing mushrooms in the starting zone, slaying Balrogs on airships, destroying robots in Ludi, and finally, conquering Zakum. I made many friends, joined a slew of guilds, and mostly, just had fun. That's what videogames were about back when I played Maplestory, and in a sense, it seems like they've kind of lost that recently, although that's a different topic entirely. Maplestory now seems to be much more oversaturated in terms of classes and things to do, actually making it an overwhemingly experience rather than an extremely enjoyable one, one that I had when I played. Needless to say however, I still had a HUGE amount of fun with this game, and is hands-down one of the best experiences, if not THE best, I've had in gaming. I cannot speak to the community now, but when I was playing, it was a bunch of generous and fun loving people, one's that were willing to help others when they needed it. I miss Maplestory, specifically old Maplestory, even more specifically v.066, when things were simpler and I had a bunch of NX to spend on a different hairstyle.

I miss you Maplestory.
Thanks for giving me the game of a lifetime.

reviewText:
Maplestory definitely has changed over the years, but I honestly think that people are being a little bit too critical on their opinions of the new updates.

One of the biggest complaints is that the game is too pay-to-win, which I disagree with; most of the items I have seen in the Cash Shop are only temporary boosts and maybe an open storage slot, which isn't much at all.

People also say that the game no longer has its social charm, but I also have something to say about that: To me, the old game seemed to be too dependent on the community. So if you get lost in a dungeon way too high for your level, you HAD to look desperately for someone to lead you out. There are also complaints that the community isn't nearly as big or as nice as it use to be, but that's entirely on the players' fault. Most people leave and blame it on the pay-to-win aspect, but I had just as much fun without forking over a penny as the guy next to me spending his entire college budget on NX Cash. Yes, social interaction with the game seems a bit more empty, but in the time I have been playing it I've had probably just a little bit less of a good time with the community as I remembered it years ago (just without all the @ spams....).

People also ridicule the new gameplay style for being too over-the-top with visuals while being a button spam with no skill needed from the player (*cough* *cough* Zero *cough* *cough*), but honestly I prefer the faster and arguably easier gameplay. Leveling is WAY faster in this new version" of the game
date: and it works well when I have a busy schedule and I don't have to spend 20 minutes slowly stabbing at a bunch of stumps.\n\nSo overall
hoursPlayed: honestly think that people are judging the new changes to MS a bit too harshly. Yes

reviewText:
First serious review, go easy on me.

tl;dr version, everything died but the devs.

review updates at bottom

Now, I have been a loyal player of this game since around 2008, despite my hours on Steam. Originally, I played the game off of Nexon's actual download site so I'll take that into account. I've invested over a thousand hours into this game, and boy was it great! The community was very fun to just socialize with and everyone was nice. The party quests differentiated from each other so it wasn't too repetitive. Everybody also worked together to help each other level up, and villages were filled with friends; until about a year or two ago.. Those were the good days.

I'm not necessarily saying the game itself is really bad now, but the community just went kablam. It's like napalm upon the nice people of the game. Henceforth, many players disappeared and the developers just turned the game into more of a pay-to-win aspect. Whatever happened to the people?" I ask myself a lot. I always come back to this question as this was my all-time favorite game and community. I don't know. I miss the party invites from random people

reviewText:
Me and my friends have played mapelstory since 2006 when hacking was a bit abundant.  We've gone through thick and thin with this game and i even won my first major event item Nekomimi back then and i treasured it with all my heart.  Sadly i can't say nexon treasured me at all even though i've spent quite a bit of money and give or take 7 years on it.  One day I came back to my account with my items missing and my scrolled untradeable gear reset to 10 slots and basic stats.  Personally i could've cared less about all my other items but my Nekomimi's were missing.  I spent years collecting the few that Bellocan had in its server and treasured the pair i won for myself.  So naturally i opened up a support claim asking if they could help get my Nekomimi's back.  Almost 2 months went by up until i finally got a response asking if i checked all my characters .... which you know.... all of them being nekkid and the fact that i did check all my characters and their inventories and storage means it wasn't there.  So i sent a reply saying that they weren't there and then the GM put a stamp on my claim saying it was solved and put me on my way.  So there my characters sat being nekkid and all minus any untradeable gear locked to them.  From that day forward i went and bought some NX and sent another ticket specifically for the Nekomimi's that were taken and the hacked account report and they didn't even bother looking at them.  I sent about 3 more over the course of 2013 and gave up.  I used the NX to get meso's and then try and find some more nekomimi's but being an item from 2006-2007 there were none for the weeks i spent in Free Market spamming buying Nekomimi's.
*Edit*  Opened another ticket after retrying maplestory and got a gm response.  Basically he's unable to help because hacked accounts" are a touchy subject and they can't actually verify that you were hacked and that the items were yours and not just transfered to another account.  This bit of info would have helped me in the first ticket but i can understand where the verifying it's yours can be a horrid downhill subject.  So bellocan's pretty much dead so no chance i'll get another but the gm's aren't  bad.

Nexon destroyed drop rates when they did the big bang patch and changed the Exp tables to make leveling up easier.  Nowdays you're expected to either use NX to get more gear
recommended: or craft some gear which isn't always possible seeing how the use of Nx to buy meso has sky rocketed free market prices making the crystals needed to craft a bit pricy.  Party quests were basically dumbed down over the years.  Ludibrium party quest was turned from a 30min+ quest into a 10min+ quest.  Guild rankings were taken down for no apparent reason and guild quest was made useless because of it.  Guild questing was used to get points to rank up your guild and had to be coordinated with the group with certain classes and skills were a must in order to finish.  Some of the party quests were even taken down with the big bang revamp like ludibrium maze
voteText:
and some others.  Nexon now also guts any decent way to get exp from grinding or party quests.  Most of the old party quests give crap rewards and crap exp.  Grinding gives moderate exp and have very low drop rates.  I've seen a good chunk of new players resort to begging because when doing certain party quests for levels they'll be booted because they don't have strong low level gear or the gear will be out of date and party leaders won't accept them into the party.
Nexon also has a habit of gutting any places you can grind for exp.

TL;DR
Nexon has slowly ruined maplestory over the past few years by making it short and sweet instead of a long savory flavor.  Also nexon's customer support basically can't help you if you're hacked for mutiple reasons."

reviewText:
A once-great game with a rather unique style, ruined by balance changes homogenizing all the classes, pay-to-win power creep, and no customer support.

Aside from the graphics of skills being different and some classes requiring ammunition to use theirs, it's all a matter of using the fastest skill that hits multiple times so you can hit the damage cap twelve times in a single attack. With the occasional buff to prevent the bosses from instagibbing you with one of their attacks.

The only challenge most bosses in this game have come from one of two factors:
1, Attacks that reduce your health and mana to 1, dispel your buffs, or take control away from your character.
2. Having HP totals somewhere in the billions, and a short time limit to bring that to zero. Not a problem for people who hit the damage cap with every attack (50,000,000), but for people too self-aware to spend loads of dosh on cash items to upgrade in-game equipment they're impossible.


Getting away from the game mechanics, the servers are infested with hackers and botters. How infested? There are more botters in the game than actual players. There's a Report to GM" function

reviewText:
After I have experienced SO much about Maplestory, from playing it since 9 years ago plus on various private servers, I think it is time to hit delete key and post a caveat for curious 12-year-old like you to see. This game does not hurt if you play with some friends. Honestly, being playing with friends is the only good way to play this game since they serve as a reminder that you still have a real life. Without such link to the reality, it is too easy to be sucked into the scheme of Maplestory that is deliberately, fundamentally created to exhaust both your mind and wallet
Because remember: the philosophy of any MMORPG is to encourage competition between players strictly on the level of vanity and facile values, being how beautiful you look, how much money you have, how high damage can you hit...... Especially when you are lonely in the game, this emotion is easily ellicited because the game encourages so in any aspect. But the trick is, we all understand there is no ending to beautiful cash shop items and the amount of currency you possess, why can't we/I keep from not coming back to torture ourselves in the grinding and trading that ultimately lead to no real satisfaction?
Because those game developers(e.g. Nexon) understand how pleasure works in us. What human desires is not a specific, final object, but a differential value through a growing experience. That is to say, pleasure is only gained through change; and after you arrive at a threshold, being it posed by the game or your brain, you are only left with emptiness. And this is when you want to start the loop again, again, and again. This is precisely why we only want to make MORE money, why we want to spend MORE cash items, and get MORE levels/damage without it ending at a specific number. This is why Nexon created so many new types of characters and jobs: they want to give you the pseudo-novel feeling each time you restart the experience, while in fact, nothing has changed about how your pleasure works. It's an everlasting loop.
So instead of clicking the Play Game" button. Why not think about something more valuable in your life? Whether or not you are willing to participate in this collective subconscious hell of pleasure looping is your own choice. If you really want to play

reviewText:
This is a game that SHOULD be fun. It really SHOULD be. It has everything it needs:
Awesome music, amazing graphics (You get used to the character sprites.) and lots of things to do, tons of classes that function very differently the farther you go along, but eases you into them at first.

So why am I not suggesting this game?

Nexon isn't the 'best' company when it comes down to it.

They have a Cash Shop. You want a pet? Cash shop. You want nice looking armor to RENT to display over your current armor? Cash shop. Teleport wherever you want? Cash shop. EXP boost? Cash shop.
Literally anything and everything is a Cash Shop. Yes it's not the only MMO to have it, but it clearly abuses it so much and was (Likely) one of the first MMOs to truly abuse the heck out of the system. Don't worry if you forget about it, you'll get reminded with drops, quests, and so on that there is a way to buy your way out of everything.

The community itself? If you've played an MMO, you know what to expect. Generally this consists of people who speak nothing to you most of the time- except in a market, in which case you get spammed with lots of things you won't know what they mean.

The best way to compare the free market on channel one is like watching ants swarm a meal. It's fascinating and disgusting at the same time...and by the way, you're the meal.

You can use the forums to get in guilds which aren't bad, but even then most of the lingo is confusing- half because MS has a text limit shorter than a Twitter message, half because they have a filter that is so picky that I could never state my friend 'is' something because it gets filtered out, even if I wanted to say 'is great'

Another dislike about the game is the AI. 90% of the enemies you encounter outside of dungeons  (At least up to lvl 120) use the same pattern of I'm gonna run into you and damage you that way!" which
recommended: but it's all just nothing short of a pallete swap if they all get the same functionality.\n\nIn the end
hoursPlayed: Maplestory has a lot of ingredients to be a great game
voteText: but too many spices put into the soup end up making a good soup turn rotten (But still look pretty). And that's the best way to describe it."

reviewText:
Nostalgia and the big numbers blind me

If you've never heard of Maplestory just skip it. To be completely honest with you the only reason I got this game on Steam was for the nostalgia. I've been playing this game on and off for so many years. (Since 2006) This game was fantastic, but it was ruined by it's absurdly high damage numbers, (which get so damn high that Nexon has to raise the cap on damage) The insane high prices of the free market, and the sheer amount of classes. (There's 32 classes! THIRTY TWO! I was so happy when Pirate first came out.) Oh and the community. Do you like 12 year olds? Well that's basically a majority of the community.

Here's my recent adventures. Recently I played this game AGAIN for the 90th time. I chose Adventurer my bread and butter, I picked Magician and picked the Cleric tree.  As soon as you hit level 20 you get bombarded by all these alerts. JOIN THE NEW CHAT SYSTEM." "EVENT!!!!!" "GACHAPON GACHAPON!" I got very annoyed very quickly. After a very quick leveling grind to level 100
date:
I got my fourth job Bishop. I was very happy that I made it to level 100 because back in my day I've gotten a level 100 Dark Knight.  Soon after my 4th job I realised. ♥♥♥♥ there's 150 more levels. I gave up after that. The community annoyed me the grind was boring (Just spammed HS for bonus Xp) and I didn't want to spend any real life money to cube any items or scroll anything.

Final Verdict:
It WAS a good game. The game is no longer enjoyable. But my inner 12 year old makes me want to love it.  Nostalgia is the only reason I would see someone play this. The game on it's own is a grind all the way to level 250. The big numbers are blinding and are hard to track
recommended: the classes have no "uniqueness" It's all about DAMAGE DAMAGE DAMAGE.\n\n5/10 Nice nostalgia trip

reviewText:
I really do wish I could recommend this game. I have spend many, many, hours on it. I was drawn in by the excellent storyline and seemingly endless levels.

But then it hits you. The level curve is absurd. The content is either sparse or not worth your time (good luck leveling between 120 - 150) and the top play is just far too repetative. There is always a best build, and they are painfully obvious. All these status effects, elemental damage, forget them. Only element that matters is holy, and most enemies die before you can do whatever horrible status effect to them.

Maplestory, gameplay wise, seems to be hanging you between faster leveling crowd attacks or better boss-killing single target attacks. Usually you end up a ♥♥♥♥♥♥♥ mix of all of them, and it seems like that's the track most classes are now moving.

Really, the only difference between most of these classes is their DPS and weapon of choice. While this one has to balance light/dark, this one rides on a panther, and this one is so adorably ridiculously pink, it doesn't make a bit of difference. You're either a bishop or a killer. Class synergy? Nope. Tanks and Strikers? Nope. I guess the best example of this are the boss battles, which just involve going down your attacks, drinking crap tons of potions, and watching a screen literally covered with colorful multi digit numbers. You do this for an hour, and if you can't do it under a hour, you lose. Fun.

There is so much to like about Maplestory, but even more to hate. Honestly, I play it for the community. I'm not saying the game is awful, I'm just saying it is intensely flawed.

I grew up playing this game as soon as it was out in North America, all the way back in 2005. I was just a kid then, not even a middle schooler. I spent most of my free time on the computer playing the game with my brother and his friends. Back then, leveling was SLOW; it would take a week just to get to Lv.30. The only way to level at all in your 2nd job was to PQ the same quests over and over half a dozen times just to level up once, and even once you did, you didn't find much content at the next level.

Because of this, most of the original game was extremely social. The goal to getting anywhere was cooperating with other players, as interaction was key to success. Because of the snail-leveling, you would spend most of your time in one of the 6 towns, listening to gossip and learning important information, getting into Parties and Guilds, and making friends. This game was key to my survival, as I live in a hellish redneck ghetto town. My online friends helped me see the light through dark times, and I owe them everything; even a decade later.

I stopped being very active after 2008, but did check on the game after BB. My original draft of this review was negative, but the modern maple is loaded with new content and 5x as many classes as the original game. Leveling is fast now; I could get 10 characters to level 30 in a day. Even then, there's still a lot of grinding. The EXP you need is a fraction of what it used to be originally. Money is still an issue, and the economy makes no sense to me.

The cash shop is still a waste of money, and you are forced to spend real $ on skillbooks, or else your characters will be stunted in their later growth. The modern community is very antisocial because of the soloing aspects. It's not the same game I remember as a child, but this could still provide you hundreds of hours of content, and it's been free for a decade!

If you're bored and want a free mmo to try, this would be one of your destinations for many years, and for good reason.

reviewText:
I'm not as much of a reviewer that is going to dislike the game just because I have nostalgia goggles on, I'm going to give you a view of the game while including my own experiences to show you how the game is.

This game as it is, in 2015, is an extremely pay-to-win driven game. Over the past 6 years (for me) they've consistently been dumbing down the game to where it practically plays itself with things like 100 level tomes which just make your character level 100 no questions asked, no effort produced. The sidequests are generally repetitive and unrewarding (and unrewarding isn't necessarily a bad thing if the quest was fun). They have special global quests (which when were created happened once a month or couple of months) every single day which reward you with gear for your level and experience automatically, you do not have to go out and kill mobs/bosses to get rare drops or complete a questline anymore.

When I began playing Maplestory in 2009 it was a simple game that allowed you to do practically whatever you wanted, you had no guidance (or very little) and were encouraged to explore the entire world which made the game very fun, it was absolutely great at making you feel accomplished and as if you discovered something new. Now you have something called a Hyper Teleport Rock at almost all times (from the global quests mentioned prior) that can take you literally anywhere in the game, no long trekking, boss battles, or sense of adventure. You can avoid all of that.

The game was more challenging which made it more enjoyable when you leveled up. Back then (pre Big Bang), to put how easy they've made the game into perspective, to get to level 30 generally took around a month and level 70 took maybe 4-6 months. Now, with no exaggeration, you can get to level 30 in an hour and level 70 in about 4 hours. You can hit level 200 (which pre Big Bang would have taken a year or more) in a week, maybe less.

This game also never had a story, just quests. There was no ultimate evil" or dedicated storyline
date: but they made that with the Cygnus Knights. I joined the game again just to play the Black Heaven storyline which was extremely boring. The character dialogue just droned on and on with no meaningful interactions
recommended: it was almost entirely just characters making cheesy jokes to eachother and other useless non sequiturs which completely dilutes the idea of an overbearing being
hoursPlayed: so I found myself just holding down my spacebar to fly through the dialogue a lot and I never felt like I missed any information. Then there were things you had to do
voteText: and you could tell it was just all filler content. You had to kill 30 of these robots

you ACTUALLY do that up to 100 robots. And you do that a couple more times. You also do the same thing with collecting things from monsters you kill. They're forcing a story that has no weight and is so clearly thrown together that it hurts.



This game is great if you're looking for just a straight casual MMORPG to just ♥♥♥♥ around in and waste time

Played since beta in 2003.. even got all my screenshots from back then.. 10 years ago it was a great game! 10 years later the game is just horrible:



Pay 2 Win: If your very high leveled and dont have a single piece of cash shop items or hairstyles, you will get mistakenly banned for being a botter, or treated like ♥♥♥♥ by the community.. oh and for the people who do spend money on the game you would be spending $15,000 USD or more to get the results you want.. (cubes and all) while spending $50 on the game wouldnt get you anything except a pet and all its lame accessories



Hackers Everywhere: Now i don't care how secure your account info is, or how many antivirus scanners you got, or even if you use that anti-keyloggable steelseries keyboard, YOU WOULD GET HACKED.. skilled people know how to manipulate nexon's database, exploit the pando downloader, or even right through the cash shop and gain access to your character and pin.. NOBODY in that game is safe.. best way to be safe in that game is not to brag about your gears or show off in youtube videos



Lame Economy: The in game Meso currency cap used to be 2.1billion but with so many complainers they finally increased it to 10billion.. though 10billion couldnt even buy you a decent weapon in that game.. since very great or even godly equipments cost about 60bill~120bill a piece..


1. purchasing equips that cost more than the meso cap (which is pretty much everything in the game except pots) will require you to have a voucher.. you are 200.1% likely to get SCAMMED

2. large trades through the trade window violates nexons TOS, your likely to get mass perma banned for having fradulent meso or even trading with illegal website farmers

3. by the time you buy all the equips you want, you WILL GET HACKED.. nexon wont compensate you at all


Botters Everywhere: The reason why everyone bots in the game is because the economy is so jacked up and expensive, no legit person can even afford a decent equips set.. alot of people resort to botting to accumulate alot of mesos



Cocky Players: Alot of the players in that game are self centered losers with 2million damage range or higher, if your damage is lower than theres they would either kick you out of partys and raids, or killsteal the map your training on.. oh this happens very often during 2x exp events unless you play on one of those underpopulated brand new servers but they even started to do that over there too



Wrongful Bans: This happens ALOT and a good 85% of the people never do get their accounts back.. they have to start all over, some never play again.. you might be strolling through the free market, or henesys townsteet and walk into a map with a vac hacker, well your gonna get banned for hacking too not just that person, and nexon doesnt investigate nothing they just hellban everybody as they see fit, and when it does happen to you, their customer support takes great pleasure in refusing tickets and appeals



I would recommend La Tale instead of Maplestory.. to anybody who plays it.. you've been warned

reviewText:
I first played maplestory maybe 7 or 8 years ago and at first it was fun. (Note: my main interest is quests.)

I remembered it was a game that, if you are a casual player, got harder and harder to progress as you went on. Eventually I stopped playing because it would take far too long to level up and make any sort of meaningful progress. Plus items like scrolls to increase certain traits of a weapon were pricey and overall the game was just slow.

Fast forward to 2016 and I am back! It's a lot of fun now. Nexon have made certain parts of the game painless and have introduced new niche areas. Not interested in monsters or mapleworld? How about becoming a star/celebrity over at Star Planet? Want something different to the world of monsters and magic? Check out Friends Story, one of the alternative dimensions that's set in the modern world where you play a student!

If you just want to do quests and wander about - the game now has a very good guide that will recommend the quests that are right for your level. I followed this guide and levelled up quickly, giving me more options to explore other parts of the game and even take on a big boss or two.

Improving your weapons and equipment is now simple to do and doesn't take long at all.

My main criticism of the game is that it seems like a neverending mess. Little to no structure and if you were looking for a main storyline to follow there isn't really one. Instead there are lots of short story arcs, or series of quests (one leading on to the next), which is great while it lasts but leaves you thinking - now what?

Playing alone is fine, and I mainly solo, however playing with friends is a lot more fun.

reviewText:
**Edit** : If you look below my original bit, I went into a little more depth about how this game is pay to win, if you're not convinced. I don't cover all the reasons, but I do cover one of the main ones. Please, take my word for it, you don't want to play this game past the early game.

EXTREMELY pay to win. The end game is utter ♥♥♥♥ for this reason along with various other problems ranging from lack of content to game breaking bugs that take forever to fix to extremely unbalanced classes.

Nexon just doesn't care. Don't play this game, it's not worth your time. Find a private server, their service and gameplay is generally better.


**Edit**

I'm going to add this in due to some comments I've been getting about the game not being pay to win. Sorry if it's a bit disorganized, since this was meant to be a comment, however it went over the 1000 character limit :

The potential system, to those who have not played this game yet, is basically an extra 2-3 stats tagged onto almost any peice of equipment. These stats account for the majority of a player's strength/damage, much more so than the stats you regularly get through upgrading items by in game means. These stats start out very poorly, and are rolled randomly by using what is called a cube. Occassionally, the tier of the potential will go up when you roll (This is quite rare, maybe 1 in 30 rolls give or take. Some people need around 100 if they're unlucky), giving access to better potentials. Note that these potentials are RNG, so as a warrior, you may very well get DEX, INT, LUK, M.ATK or any other useless stat 95% of rolls.

To get a single cube through in game means takes up to a week, more or less. Crafting them is ludicrously expensive and trying to obtain them from killing bosses is pointless due to the ludicrously low drop rate ( To get one cube, you'd have to do a twice daily boss each day for on average a month, give or take. I say this from personal experience ).

Of course, you could always BUY cubes. They're $1-$2 each (The $2 one is necessary for upgrading the final tier ), or they come in $10 and $20 bundles. Note that it's ONE DOLLAR TO BUY A SINGLE CUBE. Making a single end game tier item can take HUNDREDS OF CUBES, and that will get you almost NOWHERE progress wise. You need a FULL SET of these types of items to have a CHANCE at one of the end game bosses. This, coupled with the fact that group play is extremely discouraged in boss fights makes these end game bosses impossible (The HP on these bosses is in the hundred billions. Consider that I, a long time player who doesn't spend money can't shave even a fraction of their HP bars in 10 minutes. Now consider that most bosses have a 20 - 30 minute time limit).

It is also impossible to make money in the game from 'end game' activities, because unless you have an extremely high damage range, all the bosses you will be able to fight have useless drops.

I didn't even mention the fact that a lot of boss drops are trade locked unless you pay $2-$3 to untrade lock it for one trade.

reviewText:
TL;DR:
PROS: levelling with quests and not just grinds, a lot of classes, findable good equips, great for new players (and old ones if they can get over the fact that the game isn't the same as it was 16 years ago)
CONS: quiet community in-game, some party quests are completely dead

I see a lot of reviews talking about how much the game has changed and how there's no nostalgia left for us older players. As an older player myself (I've been playing Maple off and on since 2006), I disagree. What brought me back to Maple after the last four year haitus I had was the nostalgia, but what kept me playing was the complete rehaul of the game.

When I was a kid with dial-up internet, getting to the first job advancement was difficult. Fast forward to today: I have played almost every class through into the fourth advancement. Yes, it's been made a lot easier, but it's also reasonable now; any player can get a good diversity  of content regardless of experience or skill. The endless 10-20 level grind on the same map is gone, now theme dungeons and quests offer the best leveling chance, which is loads more fun. In fact, quests used to be altogether useless, so this change is super awesome.

There's so many classes now! I was super happy when I came back to all the new classes. I actually can't wait for more to come out so I have more skills to try out. (I'm hoping there's an all-new class soon with new clothing equips and not just weapons.)

The addition of spell traces and the equip enhancement system actually reduces the pay-to-win aspect that has ALWAYS (as in FOREVER, as in THIS IS NOTHING NEW) been a part of Maple. It offers people the chance to have good equips but without the ridiculous cost and rarity of scrolls. Equipment drops have been completely rehauled and now have hidden potentials, allowing players to find their equips without having to spend mesos or real money and to make a decent bit of mesos that help in the later game with pots and the like. (Side note: I remember the days of the scrolled out sauna robe, can't nobody tell me the new equip drop system is bad.)

Us older players are not the major target of this game anymore and that's OKAY. It's for those kids coming in at the same age when we started back in the day. It's not entirely Maple and Nexon's fault that the previous audience left, a good deal of people left because they got older and found other games, particularly MOBAs. (Admittedly, the game community has gotten quieter and some party quests are dead, but, again, see previous point.)

All-in-all, it's not right to make a crappy review on the game because it's changed over the course of over a decade and a half. The game is different, even easier, and that's totally cool. I think it's a great choice for new, young gamers with its cute graphics and background music. And if older players approach it as a different game than the one they remember, it can be really great for them too.

reviewText:
Whut.

Why is this game still alive?
---
Half a decade ago, MapleStory could be considered a pretty decent game. Four classes, places to go, and you can conduct social activities/experiments? Welp, sign me up!

Except that was 5 years ago. Now, I felt that the game is just swamped with 'features' (being that they are a little more than gimmicks). PvP arena has, in my experience, died out after a few months of activity 3-4 years ago. I'm now swamped with event quests that I'm not even interested in doing. Hell, even the community as gone worst over the last five years. I still remember the times where, at the boat from Ellina to Orbis, the players, as passagers, would do some kind of crazy shenanigans to pass the time (hell, there are dedicated Balrog killers just in case one showed up). Now? you buy a plane mount, head to the station, go into transit, and then stare into the screen in boredom as you count down the timer. Now, if you are the adventuring type, prepare to lone-wolf the game 90% of the time; most of the 'social' groups camp in Henesys nowadays.

And the grinding. Yeah, prepare to mindlessly grind your way through. At least a few years ago you would have parties that would happily join you. Now? *sigh*

Five years ago, I would of recommended this game. Now? Nah. Look for something else, or do stuff in real life. Now, any task is more useful than this failure of a time-waster.

reviewText:
I have played this game since 2007-2008 and I can tell you the game has not only declined, it's plummeted. Hackers and botters were always an issue so I won't touch on that, as well as the P2W nature. We all know P2W is bad and I've sunk easily far too much money into this while I was still on my parents' alllowance. Still, many MMOs follow that route and I've become inured to it.

No, what gets me is how far the game likes to think it's come when in reality it hasn't moved at all. On the one hand, I like the multiple character classes, as even though they feel just like all the others of their niche(Tank, glass cannon, rogue, etc.) there's little perks that make the classes interesting for a time(My favorite so far being Mechanic, though since I haven't played in ages they've likely been nerfed). That leads me to one of my main gripes: The lack of balancing for the numerous new classes. Not only that, but the game itself doesn't change to suit each new class and their newfound overpowered strengths or crippling weaknesses. This leads to many classes being pointless or obsolete(Who even plays as the classic four/five character classes anymore?) which clutters up the game.

The game itself is very cluttered, as well. I get that traveling is a big part of any MMO or any game with a large world for that matter, but if your game is a 2D, linear style, the back and forth of traveling is a lot more tedious than choosing the shortest route in a 3D game. Not only that, many parts of the maps are just lines with no connecting rooms or hubs, leading to a lot of needless backtracking. However, this is another feature of the game that I got used to(Though pre big bang the map was a circle, which was very nice).

Those are my two biggest qualms right now, though for the most part I don't feel comfortable completely bashing this game since I've had so much fun with it since when my brother introduced me to it as a young teen. I wouldn't recommend it in the state it's in, though. I'm going to try Mabinogi and other Nexon MMOs, though, because I've heard they're better now than Maplestory has been in a long time.

reviewText:
I started playing this game way back in 2005 when it was still technically in beta. I played for a long time.  It took six months just to get to level TWENTY!!
Now... it takes literally 10 minutes.  There was something great and fresh about the game. At the time, it had four classes.  Now, over thirty.
To be perfectly honest.  Once the breaking (an event in game that reshaped the map and landscape) happened a couple years back the game went from being awesome to being unimportant.  No longer did I feel connected to my character or the world around me with its great stories and characters.  It became all about how much damage a character could put out and how fast you can max your levels (and with multiple classes).

Maple Story is a game I love, a game I cherish in my memories and had some really great fun playing with many of my friends.  I would love to recommend but can no longer do that.  The game I love is no more.  I really just doesn't exist anymore.

All that being said, I have read and heard others saying that they always come back to it.  I will admit, I usually check it out for a few days every 6 - 12 months.  Nothing has changed though... the lack of charm is still gone.  Sad.  Really sad.

Miss my Maple

reviewText:
okay, so I've played this game on and off probably since I was 10 or 11 years old. I have put countless hours into this game and it will forever and always hold a speical place in my heart.
That being said...

The Good
This game is MASSIVE! By virtue of it being such a long standing MMO, it has more conntent then I could ever hope to see.
Grinding (And ooohhhh yeah there's A LOT of that...) has some suprising little challenges that make it more tolorable.
It has a unique artstyle and gameplay as compared to most MMO's.
It has a lot of charm if you're willing to sit through the other stuff.

The Bad
Um... There's a whole lot.
The comunity seems to have fallen appart. I've heard of MMO's with toxic comunities. Maplestory's is non existant. There's a group of max level players that seem to... enjoy? them? Selves? (They sit in cities waiting for people to fame" them.) I Actively attempted to have social interactions with other individuals
date: and failed. Miserably. They're just... not there. Or they simply seem to not care. At all.\nIt's so borring to do anything after a while. I've been playing since I was ten

hoursPlayed:
balance is non-existant. Certain classes are just WAY more fun and WAY stronger than other classes. That's just part of the game. (I guess that's not nessisarily bad. It's just something to be aware of)

The Ugly
It's... it's an old game. It shows. It feels like they keep trying to put more and more paint on it

I am done with this game

reviewText: I originally had a bad review of this game but now I am more or less neutral. This is a fairly old game and has since been slowly dying each passing year. I went on after 5 years and had no idea what was happening. But it is still a fun game, coming off of a game that you pay for and has optional in game transactions I forgot how hard f2p games make you want to buy stuff in them. But now that nexon has actually gotten a support center after all these years and they helped me get my hijacked account back, un-banned, and un-bound from a steam account I can say that the game is now about 50/50. It's not as good as it used to be because games are now mainly in 3d and they stuffed to much stuff in and made it confusing, but it is still fun and nostalgic. Though the game has died alot since the good years back in 2008.

reviewText: So I've played this game for a while now.  It says I have 0 hours logged because I've haven't been playing it on steam, but I've probably wasted well over a thousand hours on this thing.  There's this thing called the cash shop.  You can buy a crap ton of stuff from the cash shop, but there's a catch, it's all temporary.  You buy a thing and then it disappears after, say, 90 days.  I feel like this rips you off so damn much.  But if you play for long enough, you come by more than enough events,  So you don't have to spend any money.  But the thing is, if you actually want to get cool stuff like chairs and good looking clothes with amazing stats on them, you HAVE TO spend a crap ton of time in game grinding on mobs.  So if you want to get good at this game without spending any money on it, it's possible, but you have to have a ♥♥♥♥ ton of time on your hands on your hands.  Also, to be tolerant of this game, you have to be tolerant of anime.  If you want to be good at this game without spending money OR time, give up, it's impossible.  Unless you have someone else play for you... I guess...? But what's the point of that?\n\nOverall I do recommend this game because of the nostalgia it causes to me and how fun and obsessing I first found it like 6 years ago.

reviewText:
Why I like MapleStory:
Robbed me of my childhood (10/10)
Ain't looking forward to play it hours on end again.

Best MMO/RPG game I have ever played. (10/10)
Great and interesting character story. (7/10)
Devoted my life when I was young to lvl up my characters (10/10)
Graphics are pretty good even skill effects look awesome. (7/10)
Isn't a pay to win game but a pay to look good game. (10/10)

Bad things about Maplestory:
People robbed my items. (10/10)
Scammers + Hackers. (10/10)
Repetitive gameplay. (10/10)
Unbalanced Characters. (10/10)
Can't change accounts on Steam (wtf/10)

If you dont enjoy 2D platformers Maple is not for you.
If you aren't into grinding for long periods of time Maple isn't for you.
If you can't create new names often Maple isn't for you.

Overall, great game if you have no life like me.

reviewText:
I cannot fully explain how frustrating it is how Nexon destroyed this game. I used to play this game as a kid for hours. This game used to be perfect with a very large community, awesome party quests, easy and comfortable controls, awesome class balance, people spending hundreds of dollars on NX, and a community of Maple videos. The awesome video makers from dray86 to greencream to goldentot. I used to even make some of these maple videos. You can check them out at youtube/NaBeHobby.

It was paradise if you loved mmo rpgs where you can easily make friends and have tons of fun for hours. People were having in game relationship and marriages for the love of God. This game was, in my opinion, by far a better game than WoW until... They completely ruined it after the Big Bang Patch. Everything is simplified, new classes overpower the older classes, people leaving the community, and devs only care about your money.

This game used to be a 10/10 game for me. I used to spend hours and hours everyday throughout my middleschool and halfway highschool. Now it's 2/10. It's very frustrating when my most favorite game turns out crappy because the devs were corrupted with greed. I can only hope Star Citizen will be able to replace this for me.

I will miss you, Maplestory. You were that hot girl that I had a crush on, were going out, but then cheated on me. You broke my heart. How could you. I will always remember the times we spent together.

reviewText: I put a lot of hours into this game, it is very unique in that it's a 2D sidescroller MMO. In this review, it appears that I have less than an hour clocked in; this is due to the fact that you are locked into creating a Steam account and cannot log into an existing one. What a drawback. I really enjoyed the wide selection of classes that were available, but at one point, Maplestory only started adding classes for account-buffs or to attract returning players. The entire market is basical broken on a regular basis, and hackers commonly plauge popular maps. Hell, even I hacked to see how easy it was. Despite the boost that insta-teleporting, auto-macros, and godmode gave, the entire game was still just a slow grind to the next level. After that it's all about the equipment. For what though? Don't get me wrong, I loved this game for the longest time and I wish I could find that pleasure in it again, but Nexon has turned this game into a cash-cow, claiming 'free-to-play' in their advertisements. Trust me when I say it's free-to-start, pay-to-compete, hack-to-play, quit-to-win.

reviewText:
I've played Maplestory for 10+ years. I've recently decided to use Steam for it.
To break it down, Maplestory is a fun game, provided you have a good reason to start and to continue playing. It helps with the fact that the game has constant events and promotions. But even more important than that is to have friends to play with. Like every other game, without friends, Maplestory becomes a bit dull.
I originally fell in love with the game because I absolutely loved the fact that there were so many places to explore, so many hidden areas, and so many things to do, accomplish, and to figure out. I played pre-Big Bang update (Shoutout to players who played around that time xD), where leveling up used to be an accomplishment. Now, levels (at least early on) are given practically for free. With 2XP events going on all the time, and various different things that boost that even further like Cash Shop items, Maplestory ceased to become the thing I first fell in love with. But eventually, they added the new level range 201-250, and then I took that and started playing the game again. It had the same frustratingly difficult level system like before, but it was nostalgic.
Maplestory is a nostalgic RPG game, still having most of its former charm, and it continues to draw in many players. Though many Steam players do not play the game because people on Steam are mostly there for the large online community of FPS games and the like, it's still an amazing game. I recommend it 100%, provided that you have the continuous motivation of playing the game.
Oh, as courtesy, here's the summarization
TL; DR: Farming Simulator for over a decade, enjoyable with friends

reviewText: This was one of the very first games I played to experience extreme power creep. Every few months, a new class is released, or an old one is comletely reworked to be stronger. 90% of the time this new/reworked class is the most powerful thing in the entire game and you see ~50% of the community playing it. This cycle repeats itself as every class is made stronger and stronger until the monsters of the game need to be buffed to compensate. There's also the horrendously pay-to-win microtransactions that make the power-curve between funded" characters and "unfunded" completely incomparable. Maplestory is long dead. Move along."

reviewText:
At first glance, one would think that one would be too old for this childish looking simulator.

Quite frankly, this simulator isn't childish at all.

At the start of the simulator, you are given a choice of a job and a title. Immediately afterwards, you are taught to hunt animals. You are to use the enemie's carcasses in order to earn money. You get stronger as you get more experienced in the art of killing.

The most realistic part of the simulator would be the people in the game. They are an unrelenting force, consistenly reminding you how hideous your hair is and how your clothes don't match. They remind me of the bullies back in high school.

I give it a 5/10

reviewText:
tl;dr- no.

Maplestory has changed a lot over its ten year career, but at its core it is still a complete and utter grindfest. Though the time it takes to get to an acceptable level to really explore the content that the game offers has been shortened, it still feels extremely long and drawn out. And even if you end up actually making it to this level you reach a point where getting gear overtakes leveling in priority, the cost of acquring entry level gear for fighting some mid difficulty bosses becomes pretty high. At this point is where the game really blossoms. There is a rather decentvariety of bosses and encounters, and are often rewarding and create a cool sense of progression and challenge. But, after this point is where the fatal flaw of the game lies. You reach a point where the only way to  progress is invest a major amount of money into gear, larger than many other f2p games. Aside from that, still a fun game, but lacks the same charm and community it had when it came out.

+ Gives a great sense of character progression
+ Many varied classes to choose from
+ Nostalgic
+ Mushrooms
+ Still addictive


- Pay2win
- Devs and customer support don't really care about their players just that sweet $
- Huge amount of time needed to reach an endgame level (even for an MMO)
- Lacks the same sense level of community it had in its earlier age
- Gigantic gap between funded and unfunded players
- Some Classes just don't have an even remotely competitive level of DPS
- Even an equipment slot that holds stats is gated by a pay barrier
- An Incredible amount of botters
- After quitting there is a 100% chance of asking Why did i do this to myself""
voteText: 4 of 4 people (100%) found this review helpful

reviewText: Maplestory has to many starting bugs and crashes in it that it doesn't function well at all. It crashed 5 times in the matter of 5 minutes with my 1,700$ computer and sometimes the log in screen crashes. This is not for people that don't have patience, good internet, or a good computer.\nThe gameplay is fairly addicting for an RPG game. It's satisfying seeing your character level up and unlock new skills with gametime. You can choose between many classes that all have unique skills, so you won't get bored. But like all RPG games you must grind until you die. Grinding is a major part in this game and most RPG games, so if you don't have the patience to grind, I reccomend you not to play maplestory.

reviewText:
For the lazy people.

Pros:
- Vast world with thousand of quests, mobs, bosses, events and more to come.
- Weekly update with new events, items and more.
- Great diversity of classes.
- Millions of character customization.
- Insanely big community.
- Unique graphic and music and it's own sense of humour.
- Large of daily events and bosses that will keep you engaged with the game.

Cons:
- Large amount of grinding.
- Pay to grind less.
- Pay to get extra cosmetics.

Neutral:
- Contains ranking system.
- Max level of 250.
- 17 worlds with 3 world alliances and 3 stand-alone worlds.

For people that want a more in-depth review.

Maplestory has always and will always be a treasured baby of Nexon. The developers have implimented a lot of interesting events, bosses and mobs into the game. As of recent updates, Maplestory have come in contact with 2 huge anime series, Sword Art Online and Attack on Titan. These have been 2 of the biggest events in Maplestory.
It's large community astonishes many people on just how great the game can be. And the large amount of diversity in the game just adds icing onto an already beautiful cake.
Though this cake might not be like be everyone, as grinding is one of the core elements of the game. The game consists of hours of grinding mobs for exp, mesos (currency in-game) and rare drops. But these grinding will be reduced greatly as you level gets higher as you'll be going into the stage of bossing to gain more mesos, and leveling once you've hit the 200 mark will just not be as engaging.
This game is not pay-to-win, this will be a statement that I am willing to make. This game if more pay-to-grind-less-or-just-have-hours-of-grinding-if-you-don't-want-to-pay kind of game.The majority of your cash is mainly to get cosmetic items that will make your character look very fancy. The minority of your cash will go to items that will enhance your gear, which you can get by grinding of buying it off others.
Alas, this game at its core has achieved what the developers have wanted to achieve and it is not likely to change too much from the state that it is right now.

reviewText:
Where it says I havent played this game at all/a couple of hours. That's totally wrong. Ever since the 2005 beta started ( yes, i was 8 years old), I played the living ♥♥♥♥ out of this game. Its fair to say I have put tens of thousands of hours into this game.

It was REALLY good when it first started. It really brings back good memories playing this game when i was younger. It allowed me to escape my depressing child hood life. That being said, this game has really declined from being an awesome f2p into practically a p2p. The reason it is a pay to play is that you either have to spend thousands of dollars in order to become strong. Or spend hundreds of hours hoping the farming will pay off just to get one item with 3 lines of maybe decent bonus potential.

I dont regret playing this game. But, If i was asked if someone should play this game at where it is now. I would never in a million years agree recommend it. EVER

Edit: I still don't recommend this game if you dont have the time to put into it. I played between october 2014 to january 2015 and clocked over 500+ hours (steam launch wasnt working from when i played some of the time.). I got to lvl 205 and 6+ other character to 120+.. That being said, I put over $200+ into just because I wanted better equips to go bossing. It's also pretty hard to get into training parties without hitting 500k+ a line. Was it worth it? at the time yes. But do i regret it? ♥♥♥♥ yeah i do...

All in all, if you have the time to put into it, then sure, do it. If not, then dont waste your time.

TIP FOR STARTING PLAYERS: You go into the game and they recommend you a very low populated server; dont do it and thank me later. Join either Windia, or Bera. Maybe Scania if you feel like being edgy.

reviewText: MapleStory is basically my childhood; I played it alot in Middle School, alot in High School and even some in college.  I spent two years getting to level 70 on a Page, which was one of the harder, boring classes to play back then.  It felt awesome getting to White Knight status (being probably the only one running around) after two whole years of grinding and socializing in-game.  Then, almost over-night, it all became for nothing.  The White Knight became seriously overpowered, the levelling system went from taking two years to two weeks to two days to get higher levels, and everything I knew and thought I had worked for became almost worthless.  The point is, this game changes really quickly (as MMOs should to survive).  The tactics I had painstakingly learned became obsolete, as had my dedication to being unique in the game.  The reason I can't recommend this game is simply because it's very polarizing in structure: either you're dedicated to playing full-time, or you're not.

reviewText:
This game was really fun, it really was, i played from 2007 - 2010 and had a blast. But after 2010 the game went to ♥♥♥♥. Why is this? Because of Nexon  being greedy mother ♥♥♥♥ers. MapleStory had a system called hidden potential. Which means your weapons had bonus stats attached to them, not all items had this but some did. What they did that destroyed my love of the game was make it so that you can buy items in the cash shop that will change the stats of items with hidden potential RANDOMLY, so you may have to blow 100's of dollars just to get your preferred stat and might not even get it. But this meant that you can PAY to have your items do more damage. Before they added this the game was perfect, the game was socially awesome you could group with a bunch of random people and grind or do party quests with them. After they added the ability to upgrade your items potential, everyone just cared about one thing: Having the most damage. This ruined the social aspect of the game, and to be actually RELEVANT in end game on todays servers, prepare to blow $10000's on your equipment.

Now today the game is not about questing or party questing anymore, it is just about taking part in a boring, solo grind to max level so you can one shot bosses. There really isn't a end game, games like WoW have one, were you participate in raids with other people and try to skillfully handle strong bosses. But the end game in this is obsolete.




Anyways, they recently added something called Reboot servers. These servers are pretty much the MapleStory servers with cash shop items (except for cosmetics) disabled. No player trading is allowed and monsters are harder to kill. Some people say that this brings back the old feel of MapleStory but it doesn't. Reboot servers are pretty much an Iron Man mode version of MapleStory. With the abscene of an economy they are not that fun, but play on these if you are first trying out MapleStory. They will last you about 3 weeks depending on how fast you level, and then you will get bored.




So do i reccommend this game to other people?


If you are new to the MMORPG genre: No there are several better options, such as free to play games being TERA or RIFT, or buy to play/pay to play such as WoW, FFXIV, or GW2.


If you are familiar with MapleStory and want to try it agian: Yes, give the game a shot and see how it has changed.

reviewText:
Before it came out on Steam, I remember playing Maplestory with only 4 classes. Warrior, Mage, Bowman, and Thief. Over the years Maplestory has evolved into something almost completely different. Some old players have given it up because the game has grown at a rate that rivals other popular MMORPG's like World of Warcraft.

The main draw of this game is cooperation. Without friends by your side, the climb to become the most powerful mapler in the land and the challenge of defeating the Black Mage, who has inflicted chaos on the Maple World is a very long one. Luckily the game doesn't require much to run and it's even easier to make friends on your first day of playing. I've met 5 people myself who I owe my well being to. They made me who I am today.

Now what's different about this game? What makes it stand out? The art style. Today, 2-D MMO's have either died out, become obscure with about 500 players playing a day, and/or become a 2-D 3-D hybrid. Maplestory is one of a kind where you can compare it to those days of playing Megaman on your NES. 100% Sidescrolling, Shoot em' up, Beat em' up, RPG, Multi-Event, Party Questing, Adventure that anyone can get into.

So what are the cons? Every MMO has 1 or 2. What's wrong with this game? Well, you remember how I said this game relies heavily on community? Unfortunately, the community has become more secluded/hostile than it used to be. Pre-BigBang you could jump on a ship that goes to Orbis and meet up with some of the most powerful players in the game or the weakest and have friendly conversations with them for about 20 mins until you arrive at your destination. Today, Maplestory has become elitist. So unless you come in with friends or decide to take a weak player under your wing it's a bit more challenging to make strong relations here.

Speaking of relations beware of Gender Bender players. Quite a few players choose excessively appealing avatars to swindle money and items from people of the opposite sex through marriage. Yes, this game has marriage. Always a juicy source of gossip in the maple world, marrying someone who divorced a top player is practically the same as being a top player.

Overall, Maplestory is an amazing game that not only has an entertaining storyline, but also has some of the most addicting RPG gameplay to date. Despite what many people say, unless they put in their first 8 hours the review typically isn't worth it. Give it a try! Play for 2 hours and watch your time fly away!

reviewText:
Don't let my 12 hours fool you. I have played for a VERY long time. This game used to be fun. I remember spending HOURS grinding (which was FUN! Fun grinding. I KNOW!) and leveling my character. I remember how hard it was to chhose between the classes. They were each fun and awesome. Then everything changed when Aran was introduced. HOLY ♥♥♥♥. Some of my fondest memories of all the games I've ever played come from the experience of swinging a giant pole-axe around and wrecking face. But it was hard as ♥♥♥♥ to level. And I loved every minute. But I slowly got older. I stopped logging in as often. Why? New classes. The freaking new classes. The little ♥♥♥♥ of a dragon wizard was the last straw. I couldn't take it. What had they done to my beautiful game?

Then, to blow my fondness and love for this game into tinier shards, BOOM! BIG BANG! (Man, ♥♥♥♥ big bang.)
Changing the entie world? What idiot that that would be a good idea? Whatever. It can't be that bad! So, I decided to start playing again, and I realised something horrible in the first couple hours! HOURS! My lovely, cute, AMAZING game had been corrupted. With power creep. SO. MUCH. POWER CREEP. (If you don't know what that is, search it up.) Like come on! I got to level 80 (80!!!) with SO much ease. It sickened me. What had happened? What made it this way? Oh right. Money makes the world go 'round eh?

I love this game. But it is a bittersweet love. I hate what it has become. I love it for the friends, memories, and good times it's given me. But I hate it for not telling me it was going to change, so I could play just a little more, cherish it a little harder. It's hard to find good MMOs nowadays. This is... WAS a shining example of a good MMO. Now, it is a glammed up, shiny, flashy carcass. A shell of a once amazing game. No. Not a game, but a masterpiece, because everytime I look at this game, I remember a happy time. And everytime I look at this game, a sadness for what once was creeps into my heart.
♥♥♥♥ you, Maplestory. You beautiful son of a ♥♥♥♥♥.

reviewText:
Don't be fooled by my play time, I've played Maple long before it came to steam.

Maple is one of those games you can play for a bit, and then you take one of two paths, you either leave of boredom after a few weeks, or you lose a lot of money and spend months on this game, and then realize this game sucks and quit until you come back wanting more.

Maplestory is a 2D mmorpg with classes that represent characters that you will explore the world as. An idea of what classes are offered range from explorers that can advance into a warrior, mage, bowman, or thief to the master of dragons, or the elf queen of elluel, to more extreme things like magical girls or an animal girl with the power to fight with beasts.
To put it straight, you can make a new character, explore the world, level up, go through job advances and have more flashy skills, but eventually that magic dies.
You realize how much time you wasted on this game, how boring and tedious it was to sit down in one spot for ten levels, holding one button down, level up, and move on to the next spot. Then you repeat the process all over again on a different character.
This game sucks with ease of access. You want the best equips? You gotta work for it in the free market. A full set of the best and optimized equips has the potential to cost billions of mesos depending on how popular the class subset is. You can barely get ten million by normal play. So to make more mesos you have to learn the ins and outs of maple's economy, this has the potential to take weeks. Then you need to scavenge whats good and in high demand to sell in the market, and then, merchanting, buy low sell high. Even when you get to the point of learning the market, results are not immiediate. You can't begin with 5m and end the day with 5b.
The game is pay to win, but you can get nx buy gambling with other players and paying your hard earned mesos at a certain rate per 1k nx. The cash shop has many things you may want. All the items purchased in the cash shop can not be earned in normal play, you need real money for certain things like changing your character's appearance, pets, stat changing and stat enhancing items.
But don't get me started about hackers. This game is poorly managed by nexon. The market time and time again has been dominated by hackers. Tales of people losing everything they worked for due to hackers, with no compensation. There is no escape, and no salvation for the hacker situation in Maple.

This game is tedious, money siphoning, poorly managed, boring and not worth your time,but go ahead, play for a week or two, but don't take it too far. I lost thousands of dollars on this game, and I don't think you would want to do the same.

reviewText: The biggest problem with this game is that it can be remarkably addictive but it always feels totally unfulfilling. I've probably played 100 hours of this game and my brother probably spent at least 1000 hours and 300 dollars in content. Now, both of us wish we could have that time and money back. If you play it, I'm not saying you won't like it. What I am saying is that one day, you could really regret it because Maplestory is essentially a really simple-♥♥♥ game that hooks you because Nexon cleverly knows how to design it in a way that will keep you engaged. In other words, the game is designed to be addictive but it isn't really designed to be fun. You will play it, you will spend lots of time, you will spend lots of money, and then you will really regret it.
