reviewText: I remember playing this game for hours and hours on end when I was younger and I did have fun for that time. Although, I hate everything Nexon and everything Maplestory pretty much I still get dragged back into it. I always give it another try and then I realize again that all you really do in this game is press spacebar and spam one attack for some amount of hours at one monster, then go to another map with a little higher level monsters and do the same. This is ridiculously boring after a little bit and get really stale fast. Even though there's a huge amount of jobs to choose from (way too much), there's honestly not much variety in what they do, because usually most of their attacks, buffs, and passives are all the same or just reskins. Also, after a while this game gets to be pretty much pay to win. There's also the problem with there being too much god damn hackers.\n\nSo unless you're okay with endless, boring grinding, hackers, sometimes getting banned just because you are in the same map as a hacker, and a really annoying community that mostly consists of 6 year olds, then this game is perfect for you. If not, then ignore this game and never come back to it again.

reviewText:
Don't go back.

In many ways, the game has improved, but no matter how much you garnish & polish the turd of uninteresting combat and endless grinding, you will still be left with a core of unrewarding gameplay.

The visual design of Maplestory is still pretty garish. On one hand, enemy pixel-art is quite impressive, on the other, player characters are still samey giant heads & hats. Combat effects from player characters and enemies alike can be so oversized and garish that the entire screen is blotted out continuously while you're left staring incredulously at the developer's excuse for a UI.

Audio design will make you mute the game. This is not a joke or an exaggeration.

Don't go back. It's not as bad as you remember it, but it's still not good.

reviewText:
This game till this day is the best 2D side scroller RPG. That being said...
When this game came out it was incredible, I was quickly addicted and like most RPG players I played on and off mostly during the summer. I loved the character sprites, the anime/chibi theme. The 2D  aspect was done really well, navigation was easy, combat was entertaining, and the frustrating platforming jump quests were proof that even moving could be mastered. Back in Maplestory's hayday Bosses took hours to do and were seldom done. People cared about guild leader boards, the game broke up grinding with enjoyable party quests, basically minigames but with a nice EXP reward. Maplestory also had a great social environment, not typically your hardcore game types but people of all kinds had an easy time finding a guild and friends.

The elephant in the room....This game has many flaws, but i'm just addressing the two that KILLED the game.
What killed this game is the horrific cash shop and formally MTS, even more than rampant hackers. For a long time now the cash shop has been sucking players dry with ridiculously priced non permanent stuff. You will pay up to $10 for a single piece of rental clothing.
It gets worse, with the addition of cubes, Meso sacks and some necessary conveniences(pets, scissors of karma etc) Its a pay-to-win mess. Its impossible to play this without spending money at some point, or else you'd be wasting your time now that is so grindy. This is the WORSE implementations of micro transactions in a game i've ever seen. Its completely unacceptable. Nexon does not care about its customers. Maple is showing its age and what made it great is rapidly dying.
Hackers are a big issue too. But At this point I can hardly blame them since its so hard to progress without real world money.
If you want to play Maplestory, Go on a private server. Its still a good game, Nexon is not a good company. Worse than EA.

reviewText:
After logging quite a few hours into this game over the years I figured it was about time I wrote a review. The game is fun but there's a LOT of grinding. Not like world of warcraft grinding where the quests are all different. Maplestory is go to this place, kill X amount of these, and repeat for every quest in the game. Once you get to a high enough level boss fights are pretty fun but that's after grinding up to that level. Party quests are fun to do though. It makes the incessant grinding a lot more bearable.

The loot system is pretty basic where all the enemy's stuff gets thrown to the floor and you run over it button mashing to pick it all up. That gets kinda old after a while but luckily there's pets that pick up the loot for you! That you have to pay for... Gotta make money somehow I guess?

One of the charms Maplestory has is the platforming. There's a few quests where you parkour around to get to the next one. Those were always enjoyable (if infuriating at times) and a nice breather from the grinding.

Overall Maplestory is a pretty basic game. Kill this, get experience, level up to get new skills so you can keep grinding. It's more of a game you play if you have a summer with nothing really else to do. It's not the best game but it's not the worst either. The events were always really fun though and one of the reasons I keep revisiting this game. So yes, recommended if you have a lot of time to kill.

reviewText:
Years ago, back in early high school, I used to play this game with fellow classmates on the weekends at each other's houses. Years later and a college degree later, I've re-downloaded a game (which was quite heftier than I had remembered) to see what kept the game around for so long.

The graphics are still cute as my memory had served, and the music delightful with each swing. However, the key mapping was awkward and different enough from the norm that it proved a bit difficult at first to remember which key did what. The story's dialouge was heavy, and although sprinkled with jokes, did not hold my interest in the least bit, and I found myself clicking over and over trying to finally get to any of the gameplay. I appreciate the vast amount of options you get with picking a class as well as customizing your cosmetics to truly make your avatar unique- unfortunately, I spent a lot of time just on the class alone, lost as to where to go or even start. It felt like too many options presented all at once, and given the lengthy and chore-heavy of the tutorial quests, I did not fancy the idea of going back to replay these areas over and over again just to find which class suited me, unlike in many other notable MMO's.

When it comes down to the bottom line, this game does not hold up as well as I thought it would have, especially considering that it's still kicking around today. Fun for maybe a little while, but in the long run, time is best served on a game less clumsy.

reviewText:
I played this game from 2006-2013.  I have thousands and thousands of hours on this game.  The 200-ish hours that are logged with Steam is the winter break of 2012-13 I spent with nothing better to do.

Here's the sum of it.
Do you enjoy spending hours and hours killing the same enemies at the same place just to gain a level?
Do you enjoy doing quests whose effort to reward ratio is even worse than the method mentioned above?
Do you enjoy playing games where the majority of the (dwindling) community is under the age of 18?
Do you enjoy games where the only thing that matters is DPS?
Do you enjoy paying to win?

If you answered Yes!" to one or more of these questions
date: then you have every right to download and play this game.\nFor everyone else
recommended: you're better off trying something else.\n\nNow you might be saying to yourself
hoursPlayed: "I'm sure there is more to this game than that."\nNexon tries their best to add new content (which is either a mechanic that will be exploited to death or a new class that breaks the game) and apply balances (removing said mechanics and nerfing said classes).\nHowever
voteText: what hasn't change through the 8 years that I've spent on this game are the questions I asked you above.\n\nAre you familiar with the classic board game
helpfulPercent: Monopoly?\nMaybe you and some friends are hanging out one day with nothing to do
votesHelpful: and one friend mentions a cool new version that has come out recently.  Being it that you're on an extended vacation with time to kill
votesTotal: you think to yourself
votesFunny: "We've been down this road before.  We're probably gonna start up the game
commentsCount: sit down
column16: roll the first pair of die
column17: and instantly regret doing this.  But I'm feeling optimistic.  Maybe this time will be different."  You turn to your friends and say
column18: "I'm down if you're down."  So you and your friends start up the game and you're starting to get really into it
column19: but a few turns later your friends are already sick of it and you immediately regret being so optimistic about this whole idea.\nMaplestory is exactly like that."

reviewText:
I have been a mapler since about the time this game launched. The graphics are pretty good, there's excellent custimization, and as of late, there's a LOT more choices for classes. This makes the game a lot more fun and interesting to have multiple takes of the same general class. (EG - Mechanic Vs Pirate Vs Angelic Buster) The game has also become less party quest based (although PQ's are still fun and helpful), which is nice considering the game used to be almost based on this.

There's new engaging story quests, and MapleStory as a whole has grown a lot since the original launch date. I hope Nexon keeps up with the awesome content for Maple, as this will always be my go-to game when I'm bored of everything else.

Also, nexon, PLEASE fix the one-time account link. It should not be a one-time deal. I don't like that I have to keep a standalone launcher instead of just being able to launch through steam.

reviewText:
I started playing Maplestory way back since Patch 1.83. Or 2007....The game has certainly changed much over the years...and will always keep changing, don't ever expect it to be the same for more than 3 months.
My main character has been level 200 for many years now and I have a 200 NPC In Kradia. So take my word for it, the game is now, just as playable as it ever was.  Many of the things we know and love are gone, like the challenges, or Temple of time being the most difficult location in the game (most players walk over pink bean now like he's a snail)..The direction of the game has changed, and is much more story driven now. Before you just made a character and made it your own story. But you can choose from several. AND I MEAN SEVERAL...different classes with a pre-determined story. And advance them to lv 250 (new level cap)  by grinding on monsters or doing party Quests.

The game seems overwhelming at first, but once you get the world map down, you'll be navigating like a pro in no time. The 2D anime style chibi art makes the game much more social than any 3D MMO so feel free to take a break and grab a chair..(literally a chair) that you can buy or collect from events...and sit down and make some cyber friends! Or go gear up and be the God of Damage and solo every boss in the game and wow your friends.

My major complaint about the game (and it's been this way forever) is that many ways to grow are all based on luck....nothing makes a person more angry than to spend Hard earned cash on a scroll, that ends up failing. It's always better to let other people do it....but on the other hand...you can sell sucessful gear at a higher price.

This game used to be VERY ADDICTING...fortunately I was able to break off of it and do other things with my life after I hit 200, but the new update and all still hasn't pulled me back in. If you plan on getting into this game....you will certainly have a blast...all the confusion at the beginning is worth it and it has something for everyone!

reviewText: Maplestory is a gateway MMO of the worst kind. It's a bad game, a cluster♥♥♥♥ of story and characterization that isn't very well done by any aspect, but which attempts to compensate for its weaknesses by adding in excessive NX ♥♥♥♥♥♥ry and ERP. The normal anon can see this as the ♥♥♥♥ it is, and may enjoy it, hate it or be indifferent to it, but all the while recognizing that the game itself, regardless of their opinion, is plain bad.\nHowever, these very aspects that try to smear over the ♥♥♥♥ of its core make it a breeding ground for aspie, unsociable underageb& ♥♥♥♥♥♥s who engage in every kind of ♥♥♥♥♥♥ry both online and in the real world. The crossdressing pale white nerds all trying their hardest to look cute, the deeps, peculiar, colorful clothes, the whole night lord ♥♥♥♥♥♥ry and everything about the Maple world fuels their escapist fantasies, while the pity-party character backgrounds, emphasis on revenge, and overall preachiness of the series make it fit just right with the mary-sueish drives of your average preteen and his sense of unwarranted self-importance towards the world. Exactly the kind of ♥♥♥♥ that makes little kiddies and underageb& ♥♥♥♥♥♥♥ eat this ♥♥♥♥ right the ♥♥♥♥ up.

reviewText:
Ghostbusters

by
Harold Ramis
and
Dan Aykroyd

Final Shooting Script
Last revised October 7, 1983


FADE IN

EXT. NEW YORK PUBLIC LIBRARY -- DAY

The sun shines brightly on the classic facade of the main library at Fifth
Avenue and 42nd Street.  In the adjacent park area, pretty hustlers and
drug peddlers go about their business.

FRONT STEPS

A few people lounge on the steps flanked by the familiar stone lions.

INT. MAIN READING ROOM -- DAY

People are dotted throughout the room sitting at the long oak tables
polished by decades of use.  Reading lamps with green glass shades cast a
golden glow on the tables.  The patina of age is everywhere.  It is very
quiet.

LIBRARIAN

A slightly stout, studious looking girl in her late twenties circulates
quietly among the tables picking up books and putting them on her cart.
Everything seems completely normal and peaceful.

POV

A single eerie musical note signals the presence of something strange
looking down on the Librarian from a vantage point high above the room.
It follows the Librarian as she pushes her cart around the corner.

INT. WORK AREA

The Librarian is alone in a back room sorting books for reshelving.
Behind her is the card catalogue.  One of the books attracts her interest
and she starts leafing through it.

THE CARD CATALOGUE

Another eerie note is heard as one of the drawers silently slides open
behind the Librarian and hundreds of index cards start popping out.  The
Librarian continues reading completely oblivious to this strange
phenomenon.

She gets up and moves past another row of cabinets.  Two more drawers
quietly slide open, and thousands of file cards start shooting out of the
open drawers just behind her, but the Librarian still doesn't notice.

THE STACKS

The Librarian works her way through rows and rows of old iron shelves
containing many thousands of volumes stacked from floor to ceiling.  As
she puts the books back in their proper places, she slowly gets the
feeling that she's being watched.  She continues her task but suddenly
hears a scratching noise and stops.

LIBRARIAN
(puzzled)
Hello?  Is anybody there?

A ROW OF BOOKS

As the Librarian walks down the aisle, books start shooting off the shelf
behind her.  She turns suddenly and sees the fallen books.

THE LIBRARIAN

Frightened now, she walks slowly to the end of the aisle and tentatively
peeks around the corner.  Seeing no one, she starts to scratch her head
and suddenly a dozen books fly off the shelf right in front of her and
fall to the floor.

LIBRARIAN
(frightened)
All right!  Who's there?  Lyle? Is that you?

Very slowly now, her heart pounding, the Librarian tiptoes to the other
end of the aisle.  She gets to the corner and starts to peek around it,
afraid to look but unable to resist.

INT. THE NEXT AISLE -- DAY

The Librarian comes slowly around the end of the stacks and gets her first
look at the thing that's been watching her.  Her eyes go very wide and her
mouth opens in horror. She screams.

reviewText:
Maplestory is a 2D MMORPG(massive multiplayer online role playing game). While the graphics are dated they are still appealing.

The pros:     -Pracitcally a single player game
-Free to play
-Multiple classes, +15
The cons:
-+15 classes: there are so many classes that many of the classes fit the same style of character.
-Monotonous: this game is the epitome of a grind fest. You grind for levels by hunting montsers from levels 10-250.
The quests given are typical MMO quests. The game is such a grind fest that when grinding a map if someone other than
you joins the map, people throw tantrums and get upset.
-No socialization: ever since the big bang update socialization was drastically hit. The bigbang update brought forth a
massive increase in the exp rate, only further supporting the grind fest.
-Nexons idea of balance: when the release new classes their idea of marketing the new class is to make the class stronger
the class before them. They repeat that cycle until the older classes get to far behind, so they have to bring the older
classes back to up par. Rinse and repeat that cylce.

Another thing to bring the relation between Nexon and the community was terrible for a large period of time, no commmunication tickets going unanswered for weeks/months. The last several monthes something changed and Nexon is currently attempting to repair the damage they caused.
voteText: 2 of 2 people (100%) found this review helpful

reviewText: This game has taken many leaps foreward and backward up until this point, and ultimately in the end I would say that the game is throughly enjoyable. However, if you want to hit the damage cap and really be the best, the game is 100% pay to win. Without paying you cannot even see the top. Another factor about this game that i would critisize is that nexon has dropped the idea of roles for bosses. You dont need a healer to defeat a boss, which means that parties don't use any teamwork. With that said, i do enjoy checking back into the game every once in a while, and theres SOO many classes! all in all fun game but pay 2 win :3

reviewText:
This game was really good, and I loved it more than sleep for a very long time. Eventually, I started hating all the changes but kept coming back. Once I finished high school I quit because my college blocked the game. I came back to play for a while one summer when i found it on steam, but found myself bored since all my friends had quit playing. I have no doubt that I was addicted to this game in high school.

The changes were okay at first, but then they became frequent and way too crazy. I was okay with a few simple changes, even when they added a new class. Then they started adding a new character every 5 minutes and it became hard to keep up with the game or the economy in it. Go on vacation with your family for a week and some of your most valuable items are worthless because a new update had a new boss which gave it out like candy.

It's your typical mmorpg grindfest, and there's very little appreciation for a newcomer in older worlds... although they will complain that the server is too empty 2 minutes after making fun of someone for not knowing where the next quest is or whatever noob" question they asked. I joined the game because of a friend
date: but then I kept playing because of the community
recommended: now I would I avoid it because of the community.\n\nI enjoyed playing for probably the first half of my time. Most of the second half I tried convining myself it was going to be fun again
hoursPlayed: and tried finding new people to play with. I thought it would be better once it came to steam but it didn't really help. Eventually I just stopped
voteText: and started playing other games."

reviewText:
Some background at the bottom, clear cut facts here:
Pros:
- Unique.
- Free.
- Highly social.
- Virtually endless amount of story line to follow, I've been playing 10 years and I have not even completed half of it.
- Not a game you need to play every day, you can drop it for a few months and pick it back up no problem.
- Everything you can pay for, can be obtained through (sometimes tireless) ingame efforts. I did not pay for nx for the first five years.
- Consistantly updated, always being worked on.
- Great bug support, I have contacted them about obscure bugs before and (when they were at fault for it) they had a fix for it within the day, I call that response time. Like, for a MMO: fixing a obscure bug (flight with my classes mount) within the DAY has got to be the fastest MMORPG response time I have ever seen.
- Although it has a light overtone, it is actually quite a dark and graphic game. If you actually read the story line, the things that go on are quite morbid and macabre. It is not nessesarily a childs game.
- I see A LOT of older players on, the fact of the matter is that the younger demographic does not tend to interact with the community. The usual demographic for the social towns are around 16-30. Although there are many young players, they don't tend to be as prominant.
- The community, I mean.. Come on guys, It's maplestory! I have NEVER played a more social MMORPG, EVER. This game not only has a massive community, but I would say you are unlikely to run into some nasty people. It is largely populated by nice people! I mean, yeah. You will run into some nasty people, but that's the same for everything. I am a massive collector of chairs, and when I sell them, I spend about twenty minutes with a mercher on each chair to tell them about how I got it and what it meant to me. One of them said that they were literally crying and that I made him really nostalgic about the game.
- The story, It is beautiful. Not only is there a pratically endless suply of it, it is quality content. Their newest update black heaven literally made me cry. It was SO intense, I can not listen to the ending credits song without a tear rolling down my cheek. I can't tell you how amazing it is. My absolute favourite character to play is the Evan, it ties SO nicely with the other story lines. It ties seamlessly with Silent Crusade, Black Heaven, Glowing Sylph, and so much more. It is really deep and meaningful to me.
- I could go on, and on, and on. Just download it for Goddess of time's sake.
Cons:
- It is a grinding game, I would put this on my pro's list but a lot of people don't like this. It is a korean based MMO, it is the standard. Just walk in knowing this.
- The game can crash for a variety of reasons, although it is not near as bad as it used to be.. it is still a problem.
- PC Master race! I am a big hater for apple, however I can't run this on my linux machines - which is a major bummer.. Like, Through a windows wrapper you CAN, but it will be laggy.
- There are some botter problems, it is not often that you will run into one anymore.. but when you do it's annoying.
- Names. this game has been around for over a DECADE, there are A LOT of taken names.. But there is hope! this october (2015) they are releasing 15 MILLION names! That is a lot of new names to use! Be there to claim the good ones!!!
- Pretty big hog for resources if you have a dated computer.
- At this point I am struggling to come up with more cons, just download it.
---------OLD REVIEW-------------
I have played this game just short of ten years, I have never had a dull moment in it. When you're not off killing hords of unimaginable beasts, you're in town talking to friends from around the world. The game is brilliant, many people don't like the game due to the graphics, but it's the graphics that make the game. The story line is phenominal, in the Black Heaven update I cried - literally. It was a perfect addition to the story line. There are events on much of the time, so it's always tonnes of fun. This is not a pay to win game, I love it for that. I recommend you try this game fully before dismissing it :)

reviewText:
I need to give this game a little love...

I’ve personally been playing this game since 2006, which means I have some nostalgia for the game. The natural first reaction to this game would be that it’s too complicated, it’s hard to level up, its pay to win/ pay to do anything fun, Exa. That’s understandable and was actually my initial reaction when I first started playing. Note that this was in 06, and the game has changed very much since then. I also noticed after hours on hours of playing, I was only level 24 and had gotten nowhere. I then decided to quit the game, to come back to it at a later date near 2008. Many things had changed, and even some new classes were added as well. I tried to level up some more managing to get to level 60 (third job) and noticing I was having tons of fun.

After that I kept playing, getting higher in level, making new characters, and even making some new friends. It was weird how a game I hated with a passion became one of my favorite games of all time.

Maple story is a game that you need to invest time into to get its full potential. As more time goes in to the game, the more fun it gets (depending on how you look at it). When you reach level 120, the game really get fun and entertaining, discovering new things, getting flashier attacks, beating bosses, and more.

The only warning I give is that the game is very confusing, and for a long time you won’t know what things do, such as menu icons, items, and even some npc’s. it will try to tell you, but its lacking explanation leaving you clueless on what it even was. (The free market is also something to stay away from with new players)

8/10

reviewText:
I used to play Maplestory around 2005 while in highschool, and to me it was extremely difficult to get to level 120 as a Bowmaster. Every couple months since 2006 I wanted to play the game as a game I could sink some hours into just to get the grind out of my system, but due to compatability issues, I could never ever return to the game unless I went through these ridiculous changes to my OS and when I did, the game was so different and I felt I missed so much and the learning curve was so drastic at the point of where I was that I simply was dettered from rejoining the game, so my Maplestory experience so far ended there.

Fast forward to 2015, I find out that Maplestory is now accessible through Steam. So I decided to do a little research and see if I could pull up my old account and start up my Bowmaster and just be higher average in the game. I get my archer back, but man EVERYTHING is different, but in a good way.

Game was much easier to get into, the learning curve and leveling process was MUCH easier, there were a lot of classes to choose from, all with their own style of gameplay and storyline, and each as good as the last.

Pros:
- Easy learning curve
- Every class is good and visually pleasing
- Big numbers are oddly satisfying which there's plenty of
- Grind Heavy, but time will fly easily

Cons:
- Grind Heavy
- There are certain parts of the game where you can get experience bottlenecked for certain classes
- The social aspect of the game is near none, so it's very hard to get a group or make ANY friends at all
- Some microtransactions are neccessary to get min/max unless you play for a LONG time

********
TL;DR
********
Easy learning curve, a lot of classes to choose from and each one is as good as the last. Big numbers everywhere, but very grind intensive. Be prepared to play this game alone, as there's no socialness here.

reviewText:
Me and my brothers used to play Maplestory a few years back. It was actually kinda fun, even if it was horrendously difficult adn travel took forever.

I don't know how they did it, but they actually made the game run worse than anything else I have ever seen. It lags constantly, and I don't mean that it has high graphics or latency. I mean the menus have so much input lag, it becomes unplayable.

Moving past that, it feels kinda empty now. It used to be you had four classes to pick from, and if you reached level ten, you could turn that character into a knight. But they have added so much stuff, I don't even know what to do. Well, what I would do if the game actually responded to my input.

In short, 9/10, worst game EVAR.

- IGN

reviewText:
I've been playing Maplestory since I started Middle School (I'm a second year at High School) and I know that because I'm young I can make a few biases, but Maplestory is not a super, terrible, never-play game. It's a game that's only likeable to people who can make an honest judgement after putting a good few to several hours into the game and get to the in-game point and not just be an ignorant angry reviewer that makes a judgement after the tutorial (seriously, why do people do that xD).

I will not lie, the game has it's pros and cons, some pros would be that the game is really fun to play with friends (especially for boss fights and Party Quests). There are a lot of unique quests, questlines (there is a difference xD), dungeons, and PQs (Party Quests) (These quests usually have stories that can be a little cliche, but, in my opinion, are still good). There is a vast amount of unique playable jobs (Somewhere around twenty to thirty). Each with a playstyle that fits almost any MMORPG player (I will admit, the jobs are really unbalanced but the game is 99% PvE so I tend to disregard that fact but it's out there)

Some cons I will name are what take people away from the game (they're both good and bad reasons). One con that really takes people away is long-leveling (Really, let's be honest, can you name an MMORPG (that's pretty popular) that has a fast leveling system that doesn't get you to max level within 100hrs of gameplay?). Another bothersome (even for me) con is the amount of grinding (Ok haters, you got me there, grinding is a pain, but it's as well popular in a lot of MMORPGs). The worst con that people can't stand (for some reason) is the game is pay-to-win (from the reviews I've read) (That is ridiculous, I've seen the cash shop before and everything I saw was purely cosmetic or gave purchasable currency for events for cosmedic items).

I know that this sounds pretty bias but a high majority of the things I've said are true, I've played the game for almost six years so I know what I'm talking about, I know this sounds a bit more like a rant but I'm just trying to convey the fact that this game is worth a try if it caught your interest, but I won't promise you'll like the game, but I'm sure it'll be worth the few to several hours you spend on the game. I hope you found my review/recommendation of Maplestory to be helpful or encouraging to you. I mean this game is free to play and you shouldn't spend real money on it if you're testing it's worth. Altogether I hope you enjoy your brief to everlasting Maplestory experience

reviewText:
I've been playing MapleStory since its initial release here in the US, and I sincerely wish that I could say great things about this game since I have so many fond memories of what this game was and the potential it had, but unfortunately I can't.

This game has continued to warp itself into a twisted system for sometime now it's nearly impossible to really pinpoint when it happened. MapleStory focuses so much on just catering to the instant gratification aspect of human nature that they neglect to develop the team-play aspect of the game at all. It used to be, you needed a certain number of EACH job to get quests/bosses conquered but now you can either SOLO bosses and/or quests or just fill an expedition with all the same class and get the job done. The main reason for this is because MapleStory is so caught up with creating new classes that overpower its predecessors without focusing on gameplay aspect. Everyone wants to be the same class of character simply because it can beat out the rest with little to no effort and it is because of this that the economy in MapleStory fails as well. With so many websites to buy mesos and gear from, it's really hard to find anything affordable from other players at all.

Everything about this game simply doesn't nurture any long term desire to stick with this game. There is no Team aspect like there once was, Market prices have escaped the realm of reason, and Nexon just keeps feeding this solo-play craze which simply defeats the purpose of an MMO all together. There is no sense of community here anymore, which really is a shame.

reviewText:
I remember back in the day when Maplestory only had four classes: the Magician,Warrior,Thief,and Archer.
The game was very social and leveling was very hard. It was considered an achievement to reach your 3rd job.

I kept playing until the Big Bang patch, which made leveling so much easier. Reaching the 3rd job and 4th job was easy and not an achievenent since everyone could do it. I kept playing after the Big Bang for maybe a month or two after i reached 4th job and quit.

After returning to the game, it has lost it's social aspect and there are so many classes it gets confusing. There are jobs for your characters, crafting, and overall un-needed features that just confuse the player.

These days, the game is just a grind and level game. Although the game before may also be considered a grind and level game there were social aspects that made the game actually fun to play. Not just playing to level and get better gear, but a game where you played to have fun with friends and leveling and gear was a bonus.

IN THE END:
The game is just about grinding to level whereas before the game was played to have fun with friends and leveling and gear was a bonus.

I really wish i could recommend this game, but the game is just not what it used to be.

reviewText: maplestory's been my weird on-again-off-again girlfriend since 2006, and while it's still very possible for the game to be saved
date:
so to speak, i don't see it happening, at least not while their current business model remains hyper-profitable, one which totally kills the free-to-play player.  when your maplestory experience first starts out, it might seem pretty promising,  because it's a very aesthetically charming game.  the visuals and sound are probably the best redeeming feature of the game, and for good reason; a lot of effort goes into the presentation of the game.  the detailed level designs are very reminiscent of old school platformer games, the music is very vibrant and upbeat, the backgrounds and scenery have a lot of detail and depth to them and while there's not much of a story to go along with all of this, it does a nice enough job of sucking you into the MASSIVE world that you'll likely end up exploring a lot of it just to see as much as you can possibly see.

unfortunately, the charm is only skin deep, and the different systems in the game have been simplified so much since the game's initial release.  when you first make a character, you're led through a pretty pointless tutorial that explains different game mechanics until level 10, when you're released into the maple world, where your life for the next 100 levels is killing monsters and possibly questing, if you can handle doing what basically amounts to the same quests over and over again for not much more reward than xp.  at level 30, you go through your second job advancement a la certain final fantasy games, at 60 you have your third advancement and at 100 you have your 4th.  after level 100, endgame content consists of quest chains that culminate in a boss fight you can repeat every so often for drops, and grinding levels in your downtime.  the level cap is 250, and content tends to get a little more bare as your level gets higher.  there's a pvp mode, but it's not very balanced or fun.  there's some party quests and expeditions you can do, which are basically like instanced dungeons and raids respectively, but don't expect to get an invite to a party for any of the main end game content, because none of your gear is upgraded.  and that's where the nail in the coffin comes in, the one thing that everything i've said so far combined doesn't even match up to: the godawful potential system.

this is where nexon takes a ♥♥♥♥ all over the free to play player.  they added a system to the game a few years back called the potential system, which basically adds extra lines of stats to an item a la diablo.  you can add potential to an item by using a potential scroll on it, or you can find potential on an item you'll pick up from a monster every now and then.  an item's potential is divided into four tiers: rare, epic, unique, and legendary, and an item can have three potential lines at most.  so let's say you have a level 140 piece of equipment you want to put potential on.  you use the scroll, and it comes out rare, the lowest rarity, and the stats are total garbage.  that's a bummer, but you can use a cash shop item that costs $1.30 USD to reset the potential, and at a very low chance increasing the tier of the item's potential by one.  a STR/DEX/INT/LUK +% line on a level 140 piece of equipment can increase that stat by 4% if it's rare.  epic, 8%.  unique, 12%.  legendary, 16%.  and that's only one line.  it's not uncommon to see high ranked players buying hundreds of miracle cubes (the aforementioned cash shop item) to give an item insane stats like +40% STR.  the economy is already insanely broken otherwise, and some of the most valuable items in the game can be created $1.30 at a time.

all of this combined with the fact that nexon has absolutely never listened to its playerbase, the cruddy community, completely one-dimensional character growth and skill trees, and boss fights that only require you to be able to deal x amount of damage while tanking y amount of damage, it doesn't take too long before the game turns into a chore, and the only thing that's gonna change that is if nexon decides to sacrifice the extreme profitability of maplestory for game balance, but it'll never happen.  but at least it's pretty~

reviewText:
After playing this game from the Big Bang patch, I was around for many events that had a bunch of free giveaways. For those starting now, they are limited to 3 character slots, which is abysmal compared to the 20+ classes. So you have to pay for more character slots, and until you get a bunch of classes, it is almost impossible to play late game due to the limitation of getting in game money. To get in game money, you need to be able to kill late game bosses, but to get to late game bosses, you need to have a bunch of characters. So its a catch 22. You can't reach late game if you start the game now without paying real money, which is around $50 for enough char slots.
And even if you do manage to get all the character slots and make all the classes to buff your main character, getting enough dmg to solo late game content is realisticly impossible unless you pay more real money to either get in game money or items that improve preformance. One could just buy godly items in the free market, but the amount of in game money required to get those items is astronomical, thus realisticaly, unobtainable without paying. There are in game events occasionally that can make money, but a lot of the best events are past and gone, so any new players missed out on some of the best items.
tldr;
without paying a lot of money for this free game, late game is almost impossible to reach

reviewText: Grindy mess designed by greedy Korean hacks who would rather pile on more content instead of balancing what's already there. 99.9% of the game world feels empty because everyone floods party quests and endgame dungeons. You're pretty much required to spend at least $100 to be successful at the endgame level, and you'll spend hundreds more if you want to get there without carpal tunnel syndrome or an anyeursm. Steam only has 17 hours recorded for me but I've thrown at least 1,000 hours into this mess over the past 7 years, ever since GMS first came out. Play it if you want to test the waters, but unless you're the sort with a lot of disposable income, you will not enjoy this one bit.

reviewText:
First of all, many people who played in this game's early years are unhappy with the game because of the exp curve after the Big Bang patch. Nexon America made reaching the higher lvls a bit easier rather than grinding for weeks to only reach level 30 (Level cap is now 250.) As a person who played in the early years and currently, I honestly understand that they're upset about it, but those people need to get over it. They give the game negative reviews because they don't like change. With that being said, here is my review.

A lot of reviews claim the game is Pay to win which is true to an extent however there only thing that makes the game Pay to Win is the cubing feature from the Cash Shop. For those who dont know what cubing is, it's a way to reset the stats on your equip's potential (Bonus stats) which cost 1.2k nx or $1.20 each for red cubes. However, There are cubes that don't cost any money, but drop from boss monsters or can even be crafted in game.

Other people complain thats the game is pay to win because aesthetics (NX equip covers) have to be bought with real money. Most games sell aesthetics for real money (League of Legends Skins, H1Z1 clothes, CS:GO gun/knife skins) which people pay for so that isn't even an issue.

While yes, Maplestory is a game that can be made easier for you by spending money, if you put in the time and effort to fund your character in game by bossing, farming, and utilizing the Free Market in game, you can easily enjoy the game without spending money. The only reason people complain is because they're impatient, and is that really the game's fault?

With over 30 characters to try and many different bosses to fight, Maplestory is much more promising than these reviews lead you to believe. If you don't plan to spend a lot of money on the game to fund your character, I would suggest trying characters like Demon Avenger, Aran, or Zero (Must have a level 100 character to create, but worth it.) These classes have high base damage on skills and don't require nearly as much funding to do high damage on monsters/bosses compared to other classes. They're great for first starting out in the game!

You could also play support classes like Kanna, (3rd job has a skill to increase spawn rate) Bishop, (3rd Job has +Exp Buff)  or Beast Tamer (Exp Buff in Cat Mode.) These classes are always wanted in training parties, especially high level training because of the support skills that they  provide.

For help with training, bossing, or even game knowledge, make friends and join a guild! There are hundreds of guilds in each server, you just have to find the right one for you! Also check out the Maplestory reddit and Twitch.tv streams for even more help!

reviewText: Before I would've recommended this game. But now Maple is 50% pay to play. Plus, everything is made so easy that it's not very fun or replayable anymore... The storylines are similar and getting bland while trying to be dramatic. The classes are all overpowered and are pumped out too fast. The leveling is too easy, the combat is repetitive, the grinding is annoying, the hacking is pointless. I played this game since way before the pirates came out, back when there were only 4 classes. I enjoyed it when I was younger, but now it's not worth much of my gaming time. If you're a really casual gamer and you like simple games with super easy controls and no gaming skill required and a childish community, go for it. I mean the one positive thing it has done over the years is it's gotten cuter so you might enjoy the realxing, lgiht graphics. But in all other respects, the game has gone downhill in my opinion. Enjoy if you go for it... but you probably won't be enjoying it for too long.

reviewText:
Why you should play maplestory:
-If you play MMOs for the story, maplestory has several storylines you can follow, all of which are kinda alright (Like that anime which you kinda wanna watch cus it looks cool but it still looks bad but you do it anyway and its as expected but was a good time.)
-Maplestory 2 is coming. Maplestory 2 is technically a prequeal but do you really want to come back to play this game afterwards? Get the old one out of the way.
-It was kind of a revolutionary step in time. Being one of the first platforming MMOs it deffinatly has a decent ammount of appeal.
-Killing things is some how satisfying despite the combat system.
-The minigames are a ton of fun and if you can make friends in game or get your friends to play then its even better.
-It defined a point in history that encouraged internet safety as many angsty kids stole from their parents to buy ingame items. THIS IS NOT NEXONS FAULT!!! The parents should have kept a better eye on their cards, the kids shouldnt have stollen, and to be fair they could have used it on anything else online.

Why you shouldn't play maplestory:
-The community does kinda suck.
-Its hard to train on anything but bosses unless you are in a party.
-The combat leaves something to be desired.
-The cash shop will burn a whole in your wallet. (If you use it.)
-Its kinda a waste of time
-Good luck getting your friends to play it.

Personally I'm just here to get ready for maplestory 2

reviewText:
My maple experience So over all I enjoy and recommend this game to those who like, and have friends who like, MMO(s). What I list below are the pros and cons of maplestory that I have come across and are commonly talked about. I personally play in bellocan as a bishop because I like the social aspect of chatting while I buff players so they can more effectively beat “that boss” or level up. Though it can come with a downside of party members constantly nagging you to buff/heal them, most of the time the only hard part is training alone  since bishops have one of the lowest if not lowest attack ranges of all the classes . Just below the pros and cons section I will list some common game terms to help new players and also a link that has a bigger list.


Pros:  It's free to play (ftp)

There is a lot of characters to choose from (explorer, resistance, cygnus knights, heroes, nova and sengoku so far)

There's a live market called the free market (I refer to it as the black market because the duped items you can sometimes find and the outrageous prices)

You can make a party (6 people group who share exp and can fight most bosses) or expedition (multiple parties designed for harder bosses)

There are many maps to explore. Victoria island (where most players start there journey) elnath, mu lung, nihal desert, minar forest, ludus lake, the temple of time and the future of the maple world" to list a few.

Events happen almost monthly. Between the common 2x exp event and the less common anniversary event(s) there's all ways something happening.

You can create or join a guild.

You can
recommended: get married and gain a small boon for hunting/training/grinding with your partner.\n\nLess crowded. with 19-20 "channels" per “world” you have the option to change channel if someone is hogging a map or try out a completely new world. To make things clear each “world” is just a specific server and each “channel” is a sub-divide of that server so if you decide that you don't like a specific world because -reason(s)- then you can go to another one without worry because all events and quests are the same per world. The only major difference is the people on the world and the prices in its free market. Cons:  There are
voteText:
cheaters/hackers/advertisers though its nowhere near as bas as some games or like it was during maples hay-day. No going around this one really.

The grind. It's a MMO so you would expect some grinding though depending on your class it may take a couple days or even a week of wiping out mobs just to level once. This mostly applies to those level 200-249 (250 is the current level cap) but to some extent it is also felt between 140-165

Pay-to-win. Though you can play without using the cash shop it becomes harder and harder as you hit the higher levels. At about 200 the map second drill hall gives about .01% meaning you need about 10 thousand kills to level once and with each level the effectiveness of the map decreases as you need more exp per level.

The "free market". Most items in there cost hundreds of millions or billions of mesos (in game currency). The only easy/cheep means to afford that kind of price tag is through breaking your TOS (terms of service)  by selling doped items
helpfulPercent: hacking
votesHelpful: or buying mesos from a 3rd party  or
votesTotal: though not easy or cheep
votesFunny:
by getting super rare items from "hard mode" bosses such as hilla or horntail or by using cash items such as gachapon.

Terms  ftp: free to play. A game that you don't need to pay for in order to play and usually will include a form of cash shop to supplement the fact that the creators are not charging for the game.

cs: cash shop. Usually just an abbreviation but can be used as a heads up to tell party members that you are going into the shop so they know where you disappeared to.

fm: free market.

sok/psok: scissors of karma/platinum scissors of karma. A cash shop item used to enable trading of high level equips

drill hall/ HoH. Drill hall and Hall of honor are maps only accessible after reaching level 160. They are located in “the future” door at the temple of time.

reviewText:
Maplestory, a game that in it's early days promoted hard earned levels, items, and achievements. This premise of challenging gameplay where you had to grind away many days to earn the most simple goals is what originally attracted me to the game. The feeling of being able to achieve what most wouldn't dare to do, kept me coming back for more. I literally feel like I could write a book on my many years of experience in this game. So I want to keep this review short, and write that book later.

From playing beta to now (2015)
This game is always changing, and no matter how much hard effort you put into it, a year or so later it will be irrelevant.
If you do decide to play this game, please do not spend so much on NX. It's a very hard temptation to ignore, but you will be less depressed in the end. I have spent way more in this game over the years, I literally could have bought a second vehicle, brand new. Not only just in money, but time. So my advice, play this with some friends, have a good time, and don't worry about having the most 'elite' items, because that only makes you fall into a money trap that you will regret in life later.

reviewText:
Maplestory.  Ah, Maplestory.  What a walk through Memory Lane.

Ever since I left you, and that home I was in, I wondered what would happen to my old stomping grounds.

----

I gave it a go.  After playing Warcraft, Rift, every Kongregate Flash game alive, League, countless Steam games, and every MMORPG that was on MMOhut.   What the hell happened here?

Nexon was always terrible at customer support, that was a given for a very long time.  But the product was cute and the environment fun, flirty, innocent.  You fought angry mushrooms.  How adorable was that?

----

The neighborhood however turned.   The hacking community is thriving, the marketplace is literally filled with vultures preying on the uninformed, and the game's advances over time did nothing to recapture me.

The game has always been pay to win.   If you want fame and don't look good, you're not getting that fame.  Be honest with yourself, we all know this to be true.

----

I am going to give it a go on a stream to see how people react to it.  But I'm already thinking of scratching MapleStory Memory Lane Stream as a terrible idea.

----

If you want to call this an RPG Platformer?  It has next to no plot.  Jumping quests are extremely punishing, especially during a lag spike, throw in the PVP element (hahahahahaha), and what exactly are you left with?  Cute over-sized chibi head characters.

This used to be the go to entry level MMORPG for younger players, it no longer should be.

Score: 3 of 10.   And I'm being generous.

reviewText: I've been playing Maplestory on and off since late 2005. Don't let the negative reviews dissuade you from playing it, this game is a one-of-a-kind gem, and is worth your time to play. While the games' direction changed from a social grindfest into an more of a side-scrolling-action platformer, it still gets the same love and dedication from the devs that it did back in 2005. If the constant stream of huge updates doesn't convince you, then I don't know what will.\n\nNothing, and I mean *nothing* plays like Maplestory. You won't ever see another MMO which plays like it, and that's too bad; I'd totally love if more of this showed up in the MMO category

reviewText:
This review is based on the Reboot server.
Maplestory is a fun 2D MMORPG to burn time. The game is very easy to get into for new players. There is ingame guide and given starting meso bags. Despite its grindy nature, MS does have a wide variety of classes to choose from and each class is unique. If farming monsters bore you, there are always party quests.
For the returning old school MS players. Reboot is not the good old MS. Reboot resembles the version near the time shortly after the Big Bang update. The Cash shop is mostly cosmetic in the Reboot server.
It's still good to jump in and play for a few hours to satisfy that nostalgia of good old Maplestory.

reviewText:
MapleStory has always been a fun social game, with the added bonus that it was incredibly fun to grind on.
I originally stopped playing due to the rampant botting, hacking, and pay-to-win allowed by Nexon.

I recently began to play again because Nexon launched a new server, Reboot. Here, there is no pay-to-win but there's still many botters. The botters never bothered me since I always did my own thing -- that's the point of Reboot, you do you.

I recommend anybody to play, even if just a bit.

reviewText: This game has a long history. For many it was their first MMO ever played. While this game is still somewhat fun it has become considerably a pay-to-win game. With the introduction of item stat %'s Nexon introduced a Cash Shop item you can purchase with real money called a Miracle Cube. Cubes allow for the reset of item potentials and to even raise the potential to a much higher percentage at a random chance. If you want to deal a massive amount of damage and be an unstoppable boss slaying machine. Chances are you'll have to buy mesos, the in-game currency, or cubes to boost your weapons and armor.

reviewText:
I have been playing this game for over six years on and off, way before it was on Steam. I have really seen the game grown over the years, for better and for worse however it seems it has been for the worse.
As Nexon releases updates, they have added many new classes that outclass and overpower the originals. These new classes are usually much more flashier and stronger than the orignals, making them more popular. The new classes can often solo bosses, something that use to be impossible and defeating the purpose of teamwork.
Through several updates, the game has also become much too easy to level up, unlike how it use to be. Also, Nexon has made the game very pay-to-win like. Often people who have the money to spend on NX have the better equipment in game from the equipment enhancment system.
As the game advanced, Nexon has made many changes which altered the game drastically. One of these changes made in game world feel much more smaller than it use to be. Many and almost all of the maps have been compressed into compact versions, making traveling very different than it use to be. The game world use to be much larger and you could get lost in it and still have fun.
Finally, Maplestory has been a host to many bugs/hacks/down time. The game has been hacked many times, often causing damage to the econonmy and forcing server rollbacks. Hackers seem to also be quite common, seeing as a hacker(s) posted the login ID's of over 50 thousand players, including myself. The also game has more than a few bugs that can affect gameplay or quests, forcing unexpected maintenances.

reviewText:
https://www.youtube.com/watch?v=8Okh00nnm1w


An expanded review:

This community is cancerous as it gets; don't hang out near henesys at all. Unless of course you're like me and take pleasure from watching 12-14 year olds scream and use leet/tumblr speak constantly, spouting useless trash. Honestly there is sort of alot of content for beginners, but for somebody that has already played this in the past you will notice a huge difference in gameplay. Everything is much easier, to the point that you could probably level a character all the way to about 180 (or somewhere close to that, maybe even past that) without even coming close to dying, there is no strategy, and most classes are pretty much the same besides one or two quirks and some slightly-different looking abilities. Maplestory is simply the type of game that literally takes a step back every update, In 2006 it was a classic 2d sidescrolling action platformer with a bright and quirky style, now it's pretty much a high-maintenence dolled up doppleganger of it's previous self, that being said, you can still find a decent amount of fun in this game, even if it's boring and repetitive.

P.S. Some of the music in this game is incredible, particularly Ellinia's or Elluels music, I could listen to it for hours.

reviewText: I first played this game when I was about 10. A lot has improved since then, but I feel like there have been more negative changes to the game. Just recently getting back on, I found that the game is mostly p2w. I got a few characters to level 120+, but as you get further into the game you are almost forced to spend money. The game is practically built around the players that spend money upgrading their equips with cubes and maxing everything out. Also, the classes are extremely unbalanced. I was trying out the Thunder Breaker class, and I was playing with someone I met who was a Demon Avenger. We were at the same level, but his max HP was at least 8k higher than mine. He also had significantly higher damage and mobbing skills, and he told me it was his first time playing. After that I decided to make a Dark Knight, and even though it was fun, I was eventually unable to complete content that was supposed to be at my level because I wasn't funded. While I did have fun leveling from 1-100, making many new friends and completing quests as a group, I had to give the game a negative review for forcing you to spend money and not having a balance between new and old classes.

reviewText:
Some long term players seem to object that this game is good; however, this game is good. I say this with an unbiased view simply because I don't have long term experience affecting what it is now and thus I'm not making that biased comparison. This means I'm giving this review based on the NOW -- reduces review bias/corrupting a review from a nonbiased standpoint.

Now that I've said this lets get it started.

I started as a Xenon and dove right into the Resistance in which the class begins to take on the persona of it's intended story line. After a few hours of play there seems to be a bigger change that kept making me quit the game in the past. This is the grind is much easier. Now I'm not sure if it's because of the current model or because the Xenon class is quite powerful for an all around class, but it is definitely much more easier to level in the game.

If you like Anime and the storyline within Anime then you will quite possibly enjoy the game simply because it has some of that similar style within its dialog -- specifically the Episodes which is a short version of titles like Attack on Titan or Sword Art Online.

The only down fall I'd say the game actually has is the navigation system. Now by this I do not mean movement of the character but instead the finding of NPCs for quests that need to be completed is quite hard sometimes. I had to do some google searching to find out where the NPCs for a quest is at so I can complete/begin them.

In the end, if you can overlook the fact you level quicker in the game than years ago, and are able to tolerate the fact you may need to do some google searching on where the turn-in NPC is for a quest. Then you're going to enjoy the game so as long you don't dislike sidescroller games, and Anime. If you do dislike, then this game is probably not for you.

The graphics are the same as they always were though so no real graphical improvements unless you want to talk effects...

Anyways, try the game. If you wonder whether or not the cash shop is expensive or not then I'd like to say it isn't because your money does go pretty far if you spend it wisely. Now, if you don't do cash shop then that is fine because your not really missing anything other than maybe an auto-loot pet and the chance to win some in-game money to give you a good start at earlier levels.

reviewText: MapleStory is a Korean 2D MMORPG with platform elements. Its unique style made me try it back in 2006, thus it became my first ♥♥♥♥♥♥me. Rich 2D graphics, relaxing music, anime-style cuteness in every detail. It came a long way from being a hacker-infested grind-fest to what it is today, a rather fun game with a lot of things to do in a huge world. There is still quite a lot of grinding involved, but the EXP curve is much more relaxed now with bosses taking less time to kill, which leaves players a chance to try out different characters. Level cap is set to 250, so level-chasing never stops. The hardest part of this game is becoming rich without investing real money into it, so don't expect getting yourself top equips easily.\nAll in all, MapleStory is not without flaws, but despite its publisher's attempts to turn it into a pay-2-win kind of game it still managed to keep its charm thanks to its adorable design and unique platform-like mechanics.

reviewText: I first played this game when I was about 10. A lot has improved since then, but I feel like there have been more negative changes to the game. Just recently getting back on, I found that the game is mostly p2w. I got a few characters to level 120+, but as you get further into the game you are almost forced to spend money. The game is practically built around the players that spend money upgrading their equips with cubes and maxing everything out. Also, the classes are extremely unbalanced. I was trying out the Thunder Breaker class, and I was playing with someone I met who was a Demon Avenger. We were at the same level, but his max HP was at least 8k higher than mine. He also had significantly higher damage and mobbing skills, and he told me it was his first time playing. After that I decided to make a Dark Knight, and even though it was fun, I was eventually unable to complete content that was supposed to be at my level because I wasn't funded. While I did have fun leveling from 1-100, making many new friends and completing quests as a group, I had to give the game a negative review for forcing you to spend money and not having a balance between new and old classes.

If you got money its a real tie between the great visual quality of WoW (which servers allways crash) or a smooth running quiet Maple. I personally would pick Maple Story as it is a much more relaxed game. Great game though and is very highly recommended

reviewText:
https://www.youtube.com/watch?v=8Okh00nnm1w


An expanded review:

This community is cancerous as it gets; don't hang out near henesys at all. Unless of course you're like me and take pleasure from watching 12-14 year olds scream and use leet/tumblr speak constantly, spouting useless trash. Honestly there is sort of alot of content for beginners, but for somebody that has already played this in the past you will notice a huge difference in gameplay. Everything is much easier, to the point that you could probably level a character all the way to about 180 (or somewhere close to that, maybe even past that) without even coming close to dying, there is no strategy, and most classes are pretty much the same besides one or two quirks and some slightly-different looking abilities. Maplestory is simply the type of game that literally takes a step back every update, In 2006 it was a classic 2d sidescrolling action platformer with a bright and quirky style, now it's pretty much a high-maintenence dolled up doppleganger of it's previous self, that being said, you can still find a decent amount of fun in this game, even if it's boring and repetitive.

P.S. Some of the music in this game is incredible, particularly Ellinia's or Elluels music, I could listen to it for hours.

reviewText: Maplestory is a pretty fun game to play if you have friends to play with you. I have mixed feelings about post Big Bang Maplestory. While it made the game much easier and a bit of a grind fest, lots of content had been added that makes the grinding feel fun at times. Since I lasted played I've heard they added some features to encourage group play which is also good. Many people say Maplestory is pay to win and it certainly does help; however, you can still get just as far for free. Overall, I'd say Maplestory is a good game to play if you have friends and some spare time.\n\nTL;DR: Play with friends 7.5~8/10, Play without friends 6~6.5/10

reviewText:
Play on the Reboot Server, it's balanced much better.

They did things that make it so it's not pay to win. Basically, every 30 or so levels you get a bunch of money numbers that I've never gotten in my 10 years of Maplestory.


They improved a lot of things to make it fair for everybody on Reboot
Such as:Monsters in Reboot world are strong but give more EXP when defeated.
Monsters will also drop significantly more mesos.
Weapons and equipment dropped from monsters will only be relevant to your character's job.
If you receive an item that cannot be used in Reboot world, a mystery bag will be given instead.
The trade system has been removed. You'll have to grind for money and equips on your own.
Non-equip items and mesos can only be moved from one character to another using the the storage system. However, untradeable items cannot be stored.
Many items have been removed from the Cash Shop and some items will instead be available for purchase with mesos. For example, Red Cube, Black Cube, Hyper Teleport Rock, Safety Charm, and much more.

I can't stress enough how this update has brought back the dead community. I can actually find a party quest and make new friends much easier rather than cc pls.

reviewText:
This game has been on Steam since 2012 I believe. Since then, Nexon has gone through countless updates, time and time again, breaking Steam MS. I was forced to play MS through the website most of the time. This was not the issue. I have been playing MS since a month out of Beta. It was the best thing to happen to me, to date. However, what really got me down was when my friends quit, or I got hacked, or if I was being ks'ed, etc. I remember when Victoria Island was the only continent and there were only 4 Adventurers and HPQ was the only pq. Everything changed after the BB patch. It became SO much easier to level up that anyone could get 120 levels within 24 hours, without 2x EXP. The game changed from being too hard to too easy, it was ridiculous. Now, though, Nexon has finally caught up to all of the demands of the Veterans and have made the game harder to level up from level 30-60 and 170-200, which are the prime levels. After many updates to nerf the OP grind fest and 24 hours max leveling, the veterans are now complaining that the game is too hard. Ha! Too easy now too hard? Pick a side and stick with it, I thought. I'm starting to agree with them though, the game has become harder than it was after the BB patch, but it's still easier than before. The major updates, like Chaos, Legends, and Jump were all very exciting, especially if you play with friends. This game is hugely based on friends. It is SO boring without friends to play with. The game actually rewards you for playing with your friends now, apparently. I used to have MS open 24 hours per day for 7 days a week, even though I wasn't there to play myself - I just wanted to have it open for when I got home. (That's kind of exaggerated; My longest time on MS was only 77 hours, after which I had dc'd).

If you were to ask me what MS is about, I couldn't tell you. There is just so much to it, you have to experience it yourself. But let me warn you. The game doesn't like new players. It feeds on the old ones, like me, who have characters over level 150 (the max being 250). I really like it though. if I were to start all over, I'd only be willing to do it with friends (and if I had the time. I basically have no time for MS anymore because of school).

Back to Steam MS though. This Steam version is weird. It sometimes works and it sometimes doesn't work. Many people experience trouble with the Steam version for a variety of issues: someone typed in the wrong email address, and so you can't change it; someone forgot their pin; the game doesn't load for some people; and the list goes on. My suggestion would to just play MS through the website if it doesn't work on Steam.

Please disregard the amount of hours I have played MS on Steam. 80% hours are just from me afk'ing A LOT. The other 20% of those hours are me enjoying the game with my (now-dead) friends.

Steam: Jamillia
MS: ZeroJana
Main Class: Zero
Level: 199
World: Broa
Favorite Channel: 17
Longest friend: iForgettable (aka Joanne; she was just as old as me - in terms of how long she played - before she quit)
Preferred Character: Bishop
All of the classes I have ever created (in order to at least level 100):
Bishop, I/L, Pirate, DB, BW, DW, Aran, Evan, NW, Bucc, Shadower, UA Sair, BaM, NL, CS, Merc, DS, TB, Jett, Phtm, UA DK, Mihile, Kaiser, Lumi, AnB, Hayato, Kanna,  Xenon, WA, BT, DA, Zero, Eunwol
Highest level character: 201 Luminous

If you have any questions about the game, go ahead and shoot me a question. I may not be able to help with every question, but I can try my best (I've been moderating the Steam MS forums since 2012).

reviewText: First MMO I ever got addicted to. Been playing it on and off for almost a decade. As soon as you think you're done with it, it just pulls you back in with it's cartoony adorableness. I remember it having only Scania,Bera and Broa as its servers, and Maple Island, Victoria Island and Ossyria(Orbis, El Nath and Dead Mine) as it's only continents(not sure if Ludibrium was there at the time). It has drastically changed since those times because of new content and all which is great but everything looks messy" to me now compared to the old times. Despite the mess
date: I still enjoy traveling the colorful world that is Maple World and listening to the nostalgic music tracks like the ones played in towns such as Ellinia and Henesys. Good times and hopefully some more to come."

reviewText: Maplestory is a fun free-to-play MMORPG Side-Scoller. As a player since 007, I really love this game. The game has gotten a lot easier, however, so if you're looking for a challenge, look elsewhere. If you are looking for a nice addicting time killer, you've come to the right game. While at a first glance, the community is bad, If you try to find actual friends it can be lots of fun. Easily a 9/10 in my book.

reviewText:
As a person who played Maplestory back in...man, back when Ragnarök Online was still alive and kicking, I can say that Maplestory's early levels consists of agonizing grind...at least it used to. Now leveling to 70 is easy; however, anything beyond level 70 is a massive and agonizing grindfest consisting of burning so much money on XP boosting scrolls you'll find that at least 300 USD is needed to actually reach 120+, effort not included. To truly hit endgame requires level 210, and basically everyone at that level has so many cash shop items it's not funny; this is the norm for Maplestory. If you want to consider yourself as 'hitting the cap' in Maplestory, you'll have to spend over 500 USD, probably. Thankfully they got rid of that ♥♥♥♥♥♥♥t Jump Quest for whatshisface, the angry golem ♥♥♥♥♥♥♥ that spaminates your screen with more energy beams than a US player in C&C Generals. Don't even get me started on HP Washing and other cashshop item related tactics to forcibly boost your stats to absurd levels. It's that kind of game.

-Update-
With the levelbuying option and significant exp gain increases, reaching 120 is pretty much a cakewalk. This is extremely depressing for me, because I had to spend the better part of 2 months to get 3 or so chars to 120, with EXP boosts included. For those of you who did not have to go through this grind, I hate your guts because you all get to take the easy path now. Seriously, bugger off.

reviewText:
Product received for free

NGS Initilization Error.

I played this in 2005 and played for a few years and then a few more years of randomly reinstalling it. I got that nostalgia itch again and reinstalled. I tried their launcher from their site first. I had a lot of issues with the old one and was kind of excited to see a new one. Installed 8 gigs and went to open, error.

I looked all over online and only saw unanswered cries for help. I deleted all files and reinstalled. Same error. I tried opening it directly from the launcher file, no luck. I deleted it all again and installed it through Stream. The same. exact. error. I have no idea what changed, possibly OS issues?, but I can't play any version of this.

Even if I could play it I am obviously drawn to nostalgia from better days and I am not sure I could recommend it as is without strong bias from said nostalgia. I'd give you my opnion if I could log in.

Keep in mind this is my opinion.
I understand that maplestory is a very different game, and A LOT of people do not enjoy it.
I have been playing maplestory for years, I believe it is a very good game.
I joined around the release of the pirate, the fifth job/class to the hero
Maplestory is a different type of MMO, you don't really do quest all that much in this game, it's always been more of a grind.
This can be good, and bad.
Early game is encredibly easy in every way, monsters killable, leveling stable/quick, and money isn't a problem.
Later on in the game it can be a giant pain, you need funds to buy potions, you need to have godlike eqps" each bought for tons of IN GAME money.
You can play this game without spending a dime

reviewText:
Where do I start here.. Man, this game is pretty.. lame honestly. The game itself is fine, but how it runs is atrocious. It has issues with certain headsets, keyboards, etc. Still hasn't been fixed.. and I've seen stuff about it since 2010.

Overall, the game just would freeze every 4-5 seconds for about half a second for me, even without the set headset plugged in, and I couldn't figure out why. I've tried playing without any usb's plugged in, still nothing. I've tried messing with about everything on the game and still freezes every 5-ish seconds. For whatever reason the devs still have not fixed the issues with the game when you use those headsets/keyboards/mice after several years so I cannot suggest this game. Like, 6 years and you still don't solve an issue like that? lmao...

My issue with the game doesn't seem to be with the headsets/etc. It just freezes constantly, and honestly its stupid. Well, if I want to play a game I guess I can go to every other game and it would work perfectly fine however this one doesn't. I can't recommend this when there are better 2d/fighter/brawler games out there. Especially when this one has had issues for 6 years not being resolved, then it just not working for me. For whatever reason anyway.

reviewText: Hmm. I never thought I'd see this game again.\n\nWhere do I start? I played this game since I was very little, when I was about 6 or 7. Every Saturday morning, I'd wake up extra early, start up the family computer, and run this game. And oh, the hours of fun I'd have. Killing the Orange Mushrooms, only to be killed in a matter of seconds by the pesky Green ones(MapleStory veterans will know). Celebrating every level up as if it were my birthday. Challenging the Jr. Balrog at the end of the SleepyWood caves, and him killing me with one shot. All of those are now qualities of MapleStory that people no longer feel(unless it's on a private server that runs the old MapleStory), which, you know, sucks. Now, at level 10, you can one-shot every Mushroom(except Mushmom). Leveling up is made way too easy, and Jr. Balrog might as well just be a dungeon for Level 40ish characters. The game changed. And the change was good... for a while. Eventually, the continous growth eventually cummulated to the Big Bang. That's when things got... weird. The game just became... different. That was when the very atmosphere of the game changed for the worst. That's when the game accomplishments just became... unsatisfying. As someone who played this in Beta, who downloaded the game at the actual Nexon site, this game did... go down in quality. While my opinion may differ from others, this is just mine. A couple of months after the Big Bang, this game, once one of the best MMORPG's of all time, just became another game of Press a couple of buttons
voteText: if you will.\n\nIn conclusion

reviewText:
It's really the gameplay that I am beginning to become disappointed in.

I first started playing this after the first year of it's release. I'm happy with the way the game is growing in classes and stories and places to explore. The game became a lot less challenging than it used to be. I went from level 1 to level 50 in the span of 3 hours. Which, back in the old days, would have taken at least a month if not two.

With all the fancy new classes you can play as, the original four classes are pretty bland in comparison.

But overall, it's a pretty good free mmo
